editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: If it be not good, the devil is in it. A new play, as it hath been lately acted, with great applause, by the Queen's majesty's servants: at the red bull.
Flectere si nequeo superos, acheronta movebo.
London, printed for I. T. and are to be sold by Edward merchant, at his shop against the cross in Paul's churchyard, 1612.

div.head: To my loving, and loved friends and fellows, the Queen's majesties-servants.
div.p: Knowledge and reward dwell far asunder. Greatness lay once between them. But (In his stead) covetousness now. An ill neighbour, a bad benefactor, no paymaster to poets. By this hard-houskeeping, (Or rather, shutting up of liberalities doors,) merit goes a-begging , and learning starves. Books, had wont to have patrons, and (Now,) patrons have books. The snuffed hat is lighted, consumes that which feeds it. A sign, the world hath an ill ear, when no music is good, unless it strikes up for nothing. I have sung so, but will no more. A hue-and-cry follow, his wit, that sleeps, when sweet tunes are sounding. But 'tis now the fashion. Lords, look well: knights, thank well; gentlemen, promise well; citizens, take well; gulls, swear well: but none, give well, I leave therefore all, for you: and all (That this can be) to you. Not in hope to have; but in recognition of what I have (As I think) already (Your loves.)

Acknowledgement is part of payment sometimes, but it neither is, nor shall be (Between you and me) a cancelling. I have cast mine eye upon many, but find none more fit, none more worthy, to patronize this, than you, who have protected it. Your cost, counsel, and labour, had been ill spent, if a second should by my hand snatch from you this glory. No: when fortune (In her blind pride) set her foot upon this imperfect building, (As scorning the foundation and workmanship:)
you, gently raised it up (On the same columns,) the frontispiece only a little more garnished: to you therefore deservedly is the whole frame consecrated. For I durst swear, if wishes and curses could have become witches, the neck of this harmless devil had long ago been broken.

But I am glad that ignorance (So insolent for being flattered) is now stripped naked, and her deformities discovered: and more glad, that envy sits maddingly gnawing her own snakes, whose stings she had armed to strike others. Feed let her so still. So, still let the other be laughed at. Whilst I (Pitying the one, and not dreading the other,) send these my wishes flying into your bosoms; that the god of poets, may never pester your stage with a Chaerilus, nor a Suffenus, (Males, eminent in nothing but in long ears, in kicking and in bragging out calumnies) upon whose cruppers may be aptly pinned, that moral of poor O●nus making ropes in hell, whilst an ass stands by, and (As he twists) bites them in sunder. But if his versifying deity, sends you any, I wish they may be such, as are worthy to sit, at the table of the sun. None else.

I wish a fair and fortunate day, to your next new-play (For the makers-sake and your own,) because such brave triumphs of poesy, and elaborate industry, which my worthy friend's muse hath there set forth, deserve a theater full of very muses themselves to be spectators. To that fair day I wish a full, free, and knowing auditor. And to that full audience, one honest doorkeeper. So, farewell.

div.head: Prologue.
div.l: Would 'twere a custom that at all new-playes
The makers sat o'th, stage, either with bays
To have their works crowned, or beaten in with hissing,
Pied and bold idiots, durst not then sit kissing
A muse's cheek: shame would base changelings wean,
From sucking the mellifluous Hippocrene:
Who write as blinde-men shoot, by (Hap, not aim,)
So, fools by lucky throwing, oft win the game.
Phoebus has many bastards, true sons few,
I mean of those, whose quick clear eyes can view.
Poesy's pure essence, it being so divine,
That the sun's fires, (Even when they brightest shine)
Or lightning, when most subtly love does spend it,
May as soon be approched, weighed, touched, or comprehended.
But 'tis with poets now, as 'tis with nations,
Th'ill-favouredst vices, are the bravest fashions.
A play whose rudeness, Indians would abhor,
I●t fill a house with fish wives, rare, they all roar.
It is not praise is sought for (Now) but pence,
Though dropped, from greasy-apron audience.
Clapped may he be with thunder, that plucks bays,
With such foul hands, and with squint-eyes does gaze
On Pallas shield; not caring (So he gains,
A cra●d third-day, what filth drops from his brains.
Let those that love Pan's pipe, dance still to pan,
They shall but get long ears by it: give me that man,
Who when the plague of an impostumd brains
(Breaking out) insects a theater, and hotly reigns,
Killing the hearers hearts, that the vast rooms
Stand empty, like so many dead-men's tombs,
Can call the banished auditor home, and tie
His ear (With golden chains) to his melody:
Can draw with adamantine pen, (Even creatures
Forged out of th'hammer, on tiptoe, to reach up,
And (From rare silence) clap their brawny hands,
T'applaud, what their charmd soul scarce understands.
That man give me; whose breast filled by the Muses,
With raptures, into a second, them infuses:
Can give an actor, sorrow, rage, joy, passion,
Whilst he again (By selfsame agitation)
Commands the hearers, sometimes drawing out tears,
Then smiles, and fills them both with hopes and fears.
That man give me: and to be such-a-one,
Our poet (This day) strives, or to be none:
Lend not (Him) hands for pity, but for merit,
If he please, he's crowned, if not, his fate must bear it.

div.head: If this be not a good play, the devil is in it.
div.stage: Enter (At the sound of hellish music,) Pluto, and Charon.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What so.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I'll be thy slave no longer.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What slave?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Hell's drudge, her galleyslave. I ha' wore,
My flesh toth' bones, bones marrowless, at the oaer
Tugging to waft to thy Stygian empire, souls,
Which (But for Charon) never had come in shoals,
Yet (Swarmed they ne'er so,) them on shore I set,
Hell gets by Charon, what does Charon get?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: His fare.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Scurvy fare, I'll first cry garlic.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Do:
And make hell stink, as that does hither.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: If I do!
Some like that smell, my boat to shore I'll pull;
Not work a stroke more.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ch●.
sp.l: Not touch a scull.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I ha' no doings: Graves-end-barge has more,
And carts as good as any are in hell;
I fear th' infernal rivers are frozen o'er
So few by water come: else the whores that dwell
Next door to hell, go about: besides, 'tis thought,
That man to find hell, now, new ways have sought,
As Spaniards did to the Indies. Pluto, mend
My wages, or row thyself.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Ugly, grumbling slave,
Have I not raised thy price? yet still dost crave?
Such bold brave beggars (Heard off ne'er before
Are thy fares now, they teach thee to beg more.
Thy fare was (First) a halfpenny, than the souls gave thee
A penny, than three-half-pence, we shall have thee
(As market-folks on dearth,) so damned-dear,
Men will not come to hell, crying out they're here
Worse rack than they're in taverns: why dost howl for money?

sp.speaker: Cha:
sp.l: For money: I'll have ij. d. for each soul
I ferry over; I'm old, crazed, stiff, and lamed,
That soul that's not worth ijd. would 'twere damned.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Thou shalt not.

sp.speaker: Cha:
sp.l: I will have it, or lie still,
If Charon fill hell, hell shall Charon fill:
For ghosts now come not thronging to my boat,
But drop by one and one in; none of note
Are fares now: I had wont brave fellows to ply,
Who, (Hacked and mangled) did in battles die.
But now these gallants which do walk hell's rounds,
Are fuller of diseases, than of wounds.
If wounded any take my boat, they roar,
Being stabbed, either drunk, or slain about some whore.
That's all the fight now.

sp.speaker: Prodigal
sp.l: Charon.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Get thee gone:
That called for.

sp.speaker: Prodigal
sp.l: Charon.

sp.speaker: Cha:
sp.l: Ball not. I'll come anon.
Hags of hell gnaw thee with their foul furred-gums.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Pluto, no wonder if so few hither comes?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Why:
Gingerly: see see,
One of thine own promoters, (With hawks eyes,
That should for prey be watching) here snoring lies.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: With a mischief! cabined! A fury.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: I'll ferret out more.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Another: look: dancing a bawd on's knee.

sp.speaker: Shack.
sp.l: I do inquire if rich bawds carted be
On earth as well as poor ones: I sleep not Pluto.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Twist stronger-knotted whips, I'll wake you (Slaves!)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Two of thy summer's dead drunk here too.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou liest.

div.stage: Charon. Lurchall and another spirit comes up.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I come: if I must work, let these
Thy prentices, ply their occupation,
T uphold hell's kingdom, more must work then one.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Ha; are there whipping-posts for such as dwell
In idleness on earth, and yet shall hell
(As if we took bribes here too,) let such pass ▪
I'll have you tawed: is not the world as was?
Once mother of rapes, incests, and sodomies,
Atheism, and blasphemies, plump boys indeed.
That sucked (Our dam's breast) is she now barren? Ha ▪
Is there a dearth of villains?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: More now then ever?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Is there such penury of mankind hellhounds ▪
You can lie snoring.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Each land is full of rake-hells.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: But shoals of sharks eat up the fish at sea.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Brave pitchy villains there.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Yet you playing here.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: No, no; most awful Pluto.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Were you good hellhounds, every day should be
A Symon-and-iude, to crown our board with feasts
A black-eyed-soul each minute: were you honest devil ▪
Each officer in hell should have at least,
A brace of whores to his breakfast: above us dwell,
Devils braver and more subtle than in hell.

sp.speaker: Omni.
sp.l: We'll fill thy palace with them.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: I'll try that: go:
Rufman, take instantly a courtier's shape
Of any country: choose thine own disguise
And return swiftly.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Shackle-soul wear thou
A friar's grave habit.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Grumshall walk thou
In treble-ruffs like a merchant.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So: 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: The bars of our litigious courts had wont
To crack with thronging pleaders, whose loud din
Shook the infernal hell, as if 't had been
An earthquake bursting from the deep abyss,
Or else Jove's thunder, thrown at the head of Dis
(The god of gold,) for hiding it below,
Thereby to tempt churls hither. Nor did we know
What a vacation meant: continual term
Fattened hell's lawyers, and shall so again.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Command us.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Fly into the world:
As you're in shapes transformed be so in name,
For men are our sides only: be you the same;
〈◊〉 thee to Naples, (Rufman), thou shalt find
A prince there (Newly crowned,) apply inclined de
To any bendings ▪ least his youthful brows
〈◊〉 at stars only, weigh down his loftiest boughs
With leaden plome●● poison his best thoughts with taste
Of things most sensual; if the heart once waste
the body feels consumption; good or bad Kings
Breed subjects like them: clear streams flow from clear springs.
Turn therefore Naples to a puddle: with a civil
Much promising face, and well oiled play the court devil.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: I'll do't in bravery: if as deep as hell,
Thy large ears hear a land curse me, my part's played well.

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Fly shackle-soul.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: To the friary,
Best-famed in Naples for strict orders: throw
What nets thou seest can catch them: amongst 'em sow
Seeds of contention, or whatever sin
They most abhor, sweat thou to bring that in.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: A wolf in lamb skin leaps into the rout,
Bell, book, or candle cannot curse me out:
I'll curse faster than they.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Do:

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Be thou a city-devil, make thy hands
Of harpies claws, which being on courtiers lands
Once fastened, never let loose, the merchant play,
And on the burse, see thou thy flag display.
Of politic bankruptness: train up as many
To f●●ght under it, as thou canst, for now's not any
That break, (They'll break their necks first) if, beside
Thou canst not through the whole city meet with pride,
Riot, lechery, envy, avarice, and such stuff,
Bring 'em all-in coached, the gares are wide enough.
The spirit of gold instruct thee: hence all.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Fly.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Stay, lest you should want helpers at your calling
Any devils shall come, (Search hound, tobacco-spawling,
Upshotten, Suckland, glitterback, or any
Whom you shall need to employ, but call not many,
There's but few good in hell. And stay, remember
We all meet to hear how you prosper.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: The tree
Blasted with goblins, that about whose root
5. Mandrakes grow, i'th grove by Naples there,
Meet there.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We shall.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Our blessings with you bear.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Dread King of ghosts, we'll ply our thrift so well,
Thou shalt be forced to enlarge thy jail of hell.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Be quick th'at best, let saucy mortals know,
Howe'er they sleep, there's one wakes here below.

div.stage: ¶ Enter Alphonso (King of Naples) crowned, wearing robes Imperiall, swords of state, maces, etc. being born before him, by Octavio Astolfo, (2. uncles) Narcisso, Jovinelli, Brisco, (Counts) with others, count Spendola meeting them.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: One of those gallant troops went forth to meet
Your admired mistress (Erminhild the fair)
Hath left your convoy with her on the way.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And brings glad news of her being here (This day)
Let canons tell in thunder her arrival,
When she's at hand ourself will meet her,

div.stage: Flourish omn. on. He takes his seat; all kneel.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Pray rise; until about our brows were thrown,
These sparkling beams, such adoration
Was not bestowed on us: whom does the knee
Thus lovely worship? this idol, (Gold) or me?
Indeed 'tis the world's saint, if that you adore,
Go, pray to your coffers. None to us shall bow,
Give God your knees.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Whose own voice does allow
That subjects should to those who are supreme,
Bend, as to God, (All Kings being like to him)

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Thou wonder of thy time, I'll pay no more
To thee of duty than has been before
And ever shall be paid to those sit high.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Pray mock not me with such idolatry,
Kings, gods are, (I confess) but gods of clay,
Brittle as you are, you as good as they,
Only in weight they differ, (This poor dram)
Yet all but flesh and blood; and such I am.
If such, pray let me eat, drink, speak, and walk,
Not looked clean through, with superstitious eyes,
(Not stared at like a comet.) As you go
Or speak, or feed, (Un wondered at) let me so ▪

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Not Kings of ceremony.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Uncle what then?
Still are they Kings.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: But show like common men.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Good uncle know, no sun in this our sphere,
Shall rule but we, let others shine as clear,
In goodness, none in greatness shall.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Blessed reign!
The golden world is moulding new again.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: All that I crave is this, and 'tis not new,
Pay unto Caesar only Caesar's due.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: We owe thee loyal hearts, and those we'll pay,
Each minute (Mirror of Kings.)

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Mark, the old lords promise their hearts, but no money.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Here are the names of bold conspirators,
(Young Catilines, and far more desperate)
Who in your father's days kindled the fires
Of here rebellion.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Which are now burned out.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Who knows that? embers in dead ashes lie.
King, set thy hand to this let traitors die.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: 'Tis fit you should do so.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Sound policy.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Men many things hold fit,
That are not good,
A young beginner and set up in blood!
(Butchers can do no more.)
Shall records say
Being crowned, he played the tyrant the first day,
How should that chronicler be cursed? your paper.
When such a fatal book comes in my sight,
I'll with Vespasian wish I could not write,
Their bond is cancelled. I forgive the debt,
See that at liberty, they all be set.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A princely act.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If wisely 'tis well done.

sp.speaker: Sp●n.
sp.l: That reign must boast,
Which mercy has begun.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bear witness all, what pace the chariot wheels
Of our new guided sovereignty shall run.

sp.speaker: Rus.
sp.l: A main gallop I hope.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And here I vow to end as 'tis begun.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Heaven fill thee full of days,
But (Being all told)
Ending no worse,
Their sum we'll write in gold.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The course you'll take dear lord.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This: pray observe it.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.p: Call you this coronation day? would I were ith' streets where the conduits run claret wine, there's some good fellowship.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Each week within the year shall be a book
Which each day I'll read o'er: I well may do't,
The book being but six leaves (Six days,) the seventh
Be his that owes it;
Sacred is that and high;
And who profanes one hour in that,
Shall die.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: How many will be left alive then this day fortnight?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: First, beat all taverns down then, souls are lost
(Being drowned in surfeits) on that seventh day most.
Stay (Best of Kings) mine own hand shall set down
What laws thou madest first day thou worest a crown.
Begin, begin thy week.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Write Monday.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: So so, Monday.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.p: They say monday's shoemaker's holiday, I'll fall to that trade.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I have writ it down my liege.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Peace, harken to your lesson.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: That day, from morn till night, I'll execute
The office of a judge, and weigh out laws
With even scales.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: That's more than grocers do.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The poor and rich man's cause
I'll poise alike: it shall be my chief care
That bribes and wrangling be pitched o'er the bar.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: We shall have old breaking of necks then.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Down with that first.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: O for a pen of gold!
You'll have no bribes.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Yet termtime all they year!
A good strong law, suit cannot now cost dear.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Have you done?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I'm at bribes, and wrangling done presently.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.p: We must all turn pettifoggers, and in stead of gilt rapiers, hang buckram bags at our girdles.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: All my clients, shall be women.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.p: Because they are easiest fetched over: there's something to be gotten out of them.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Thy Monday's task is done: what's next?

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Sunday if the week goes backward.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tuesdayes we'll sit to hear the poor-man's cries,
Orphans and widows: our own princely eyes
Shall their petitions read: our progress then
Shall be to hospitals which good minded men
Have built to pious use, for lame, sicks, and poor
We'll see what's given, what spent, and what flows o'er
Churls (With God's money) shall not feast, swill wine,
And fat their rank guts whilst poor wretches pine.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: This is a brave world for beggars, if it hold.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Poor wretches pine, so are they left: to th' next.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Wednesdaies we'll spend.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: In fish dinners.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: In th' affairs
Of foreign states, treat with ambassadors,
Hear them and give them answers. Thursday, for wars.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.p: That's well: better be together by th'ears, than to go halting to hospitals.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Our Neapolitan youths (That day) shall try
Their skill in arms, poor scorned soldiers
Shall not be suffered beg here (As in some lands)
Nor stoop slavelike to captains proud commands,
Starve, and lie nasty, when the selfsame pay,
The soldier fights for, keeps the leaders gay.
Nor shall he through ice and fire make grey his bread,
Wear out new moons, only to earn his bread,
Wade up to'th beard in torrents; and be drowned
All save the head; march hard to meet a wound,
I'th very face, and even his heartstrings crack,
To win a town, yet not to clothe his back:
And the black storm of troubles being gone,
Shunned like a creditor, not looked upon,
But as court-palates (When bright day draws nigh)
Rolled up in some dark corner is thrown by.
Uncle write that.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Fast as my pen can trot.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.p:
What a number of tottered rogues will be turned into brave
fellows a this new change of the moon

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: The braver they are, the sooner are mercers undone.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Soldiers are down too.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Down with learning next.
For Friday shall be spent it'h reverend schools,
Where we'll sift bran from hour, (Hiss babbling fools,
But crown the deep-brained disputant) none shall hold
Three or four church-livings (Got by simonious gold)
In them, to fat himself as in a sty,
When greater scholars languish in beggary:
And in thin threadbare cassocks wear out their age,
And bury their worth in some by vicarage:
This we'll see mended.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Tithe pigs you'll smoke for this.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: So set it down.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Scholars languish in beggery-so:
Thy Fridaies law is writ; for Saturday, what?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I marry sir, all our cares now for that.
Well to begin, and not end so were base,
The winning of the goal crowns each man's race.

div.stage: Narcisso stepping in before in the scene, enters here.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: Sir, there's a stranger newly arrived your court,
And much importunes to behold your highness.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: Of goodly presence.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Let him see us.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: The powers that guide me, guard thee, I have heard thy name
In regions far hence, where it does resound
Louder than here at home; to touch this ground
I ha' passed through countries, into which none here
Would willingly sail I think, and with me bring,
My love and service, which to your grace I tender.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What are you, and whence come you?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: From Helvetia.

sp.speaker: Spen:
sp.l: What hell says he?

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Peace you shall know hot hell time enough.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.p: I am an Helvetian born, the house from which I am descended, ancient and well known to many princes: Bohor is my name.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Zounds! Bohor! has struck two of my teeth out with his name,

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: A Shalcan Tartar being my grandfather
Men call me Shalkan Bohor. About the world
My travails make a girdle (Perfect round:)
So that, what wonders Kings on earth ever found
I know, and what I know, is yours.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Brave Helvetian,
We give you thanks and welcome: your arrival ▪
Is fair and to our wish, of those days
Which time sets down, to number up a week,
Every day have we tasked; save only one,
How in these courts of Kings (Through which you have gone,)
Do princes waste their hours?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: How but in that,
For which they are born Kings? (Pleasure:) every man's aim,
Is to his pleasure: only 'tis change in name,
That's all the difference; are King's tyrants? Blood
Is then their pleasure: thirst they after wars!
Ambition tickles them; that for which man most cares,
Good or bad, 'tis his pleasure, and to gain it,
His soul must compass it though hell restrain it ▪
To this mark all men's thoughts, creation drew,
That all might strive for a thing, that's got by few:
Who are those few but Kings? and 'tis fit they
Should have it, because true pleasure does soon decay.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How like you his counsel?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Rarely.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What ruffian's this?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bohor thou'st warmed our young blood; all cares of state;
Shall that day sleep, to ourself we'll Saturday have,
Pleasure (The slave of Kings shall then be our slave,
lords let there be a proclamation drawn,
What man soever (Strange or native born,)
Can feast our spleen, and heigthen our delight,
He shall have gold and be our favourite.
Tilts, turneys, masques, plays, dancing, drinking deep
Though ere noon all Naples lie dead-drunk asleep .

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: How King?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: We'll have it so un●le.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Down with that too.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Print Saturday in great text letters.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Well, well, it shall.
Our swan turns crow, poisoned with one drop of gall.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I'll have this proclamation forthwith drawn.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: And publish all the days.

sp.speaker: Prisoner
sp.l: And Saturday.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.p: Especially that at large if you can in red, like a dominical letter.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Go see it done.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: My task.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why sigh you? Of six days would you not spare me one?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Thine own laws from thine own mouth, we'll proclaim, if thine own words thou hear'st, be't thine own shame.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Your long expected happiness is arrived,
The Princess of Calabria.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou crownest me again ▪
Dear uncle, honoured lords, with our whole court
Honour her hither; I am rapt with joy,
And lost till I behold her: fetch me my love.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I fear deep whirlpools though it run smooth above.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: To our worthy friend your welcomes.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: But pray sir tell us, mean you that we indeed
Shall have but one playing day through the whole week?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: All iovinells, we'll be jovial all.

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: Till Saturday came, we lived in terrible fear.
Thank Bohor, who your dead spirits up did rear.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Had I (As first I did begin) gone on,
I like a schoolboy should have worn my crown,
As if I had borrowed it.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: Had been most vile.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I'll be a sea, (Boundless.)

sp.speaker: Spen:
sp.l: Thou art a sun,
And let no base clouds muffle thee.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Brave Kings all!
Crown, sceptre, court, city, country, are at your call ▪

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: There spoke young love indeed.

sp.speaker: Prisoner
sp.l: The tide now turns.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: And now we'll swim.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And laugh, though the whole world mourns.

sp.speaker: Flourish.
sp.l: Omn: tantara, heigh.

sp.speaker: Trūpets
sp.l: Erminghild brought in.

div.stage: Enter Octavio and Astolphe, ushering Erminhild, attended by ladies and others.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: Call up your lustiest spirits: the lady's come.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: O my earthly bliss! embraces! kisses! how sweet
Are you to parted lovers when they meet?
That entertainment which the Duke your father,
Lent royally (Late to me,) I now can pay
At a King's charge: to our Neapolitan court,
None (Brightest Erminhild can come longed for
More than yourself.) You have stolen upon us (Lady)

sp.speaker: Erm:
sp.l: You have good law against me, (Playing the thief)
Your grace may keep me prisoner.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: In these arms;
From whence not Jove shall ransom thee; we twain
Will wed, and bed, and get a prince shall reign
In Naples bravely, when we both lie dead:
Till then, pleasure's wings, to their full breadth be spread.

div.stage: Enter scumbroth, ringing a bell; Alphege, a friar, and Shacklesoul, in a friar's weed, with cloth to lay.

sp.speaker: Scum.
sp.p: A manger, a manger, a manger, I must needs have a mangy voice, when I do nothing but ball for a company of hungry scabs; a manger.

sp.speaker: Alph:
sp.l: You must be nimble rush.

sp.speaker: Sha:
sp.l: As a drawer in a new tavern, first day the bush is hung up.

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.l: A manger, a manger, a manger,

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: So: the lord prior's napkin here, there the subpiors: his knife and case of picktooths thus: as for the convent, let them lick their fingers in stead of wiping, and suck their teeth in steed of picking.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: What other duty sir, must I call mine?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: As you are novice, you are to say grace demurely, wait on the prior's trencher soberly, steal away a mouthful cunningly, and munch it up in a corner hungerly. Ply your office, rush.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.l: Thanks good friar Alphege: yes, shackle-soul will play
The task he's set to: devils never idle lie:
Friar rush! ha, ha: you've now an excellent choir,
To sing in hell, the devil and the friar.

div.stage: Enter prior, subprior, Alphege, Hillary, rush, and other friars. All sit: dishes brought in before.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Where's Rush, our junior novice?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Here lord prior.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Stand forth, and render thanks.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Hum, hum:
For our bread, wine, ale and beer,
For the piping hot meats here:
For broths of sundry tastes and sort,
For beef, veal, mutton, lamb, and pork.
Greensauce with calf's head and bacon,
Big and goose, and crammed-up capon.
For past razed stiff with curious art,
Pie, custard, Florentine and tart.
Baked rumps, fried kidneys, and lamstones,
Fat sweetbreads, luscious maribones,
Artichoke, and oyster-pies,
Buttered crab, prawns, lobsters thighs,
Thanks be given for flesh and fishes,
With this choice of tempting dishes:
To which proface: with bly the looks sit ye,

sp.speaker: Rush.
sp.l: Bids this convent, much good do't ye.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: How dar'st thou mock us thou ill nurtured slave?

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Contemnest thou our order and religious fare?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: He has spoken treason to all our stomachs.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Down with the villain.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Mischief on us waits
If we feed so vile a wretch.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Thrust him out at gates.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I do conjure you by my hallowed beads
To hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Canst thou excuse thyself?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Alas (My lord) I thought it had been here
As in the neighbouring churches, where the poor'st vicar
Is filled up to the chin with choice of meats,
Yet seeks new ways to whet dull appetite,
As there with holy spells men's souls they cherish,
So with delicious fare, they themselves nourish.
Nor want they argument for sweet belly-cheer
To prove it lawful.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Most profane and fearful.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: But since your order (Pious and reverend)
Tied to religious fasts, spends the sad day
Wholly in meager contemplation,
I absolution beg on both my knees,
For what my tongue offended in: 'las! poor rush
(See't by his cheeks) eats little: I can feed
On roots, and drink the water of the spring
Out of mine own cup: make an anatomy
Of my most sinful carcase: then pardon me.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Thy ignorance is thy pardon, we believe thee.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Gratias reverenda dominae prior.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: But do our brothers in parts more remote,
Feed so delicious sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Rush cannot lie.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Thou falsely dost accuse those holy men.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: How can it stand with their profession?

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Thou sayest (Vile young man) they have arguments
to prove it lawful gluttonously to feed.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Rush, answer the subprior.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: Audite fratres, they do not only prove it lawful, but make it palpable, that he who eats not good in eat is damned.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Benedicite.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: What shall become of all us then?

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Thou art distracted, whence canst thou force argument?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: From silly reason, would you hear me speak?

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Speak freely and be bold, listen.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: He that eats not good meat is damned: sie dispute.
If he that feeds well hath a good soul, then è contra.
No, he that feeds ill, hath a bad and a poor soul.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: That's we.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: And so consequently is damned, for who regards poor souls? and if they be not regarded they are cast forth, and if cast forth, than they are damned.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: I deny your minor, he that feeds well hath a good soul.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: Sic probo: the soul follows the temperature of the body, he that feeds well hath a good temperature of body, ergo, he that feeds well hath a good soul.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: A full and edifying argument.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: I deny that the soul follows the temperature of the body.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: Anima sequitur temperaturā corporis, it is a principle, et contra principia non est disputandum, all we.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: It's most apparent.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: O most learned rush!

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: A shallow sophister, hear me farther.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.p: Subprior, we'll hear the rest disputed at our leisure: you take too much upon you.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Shall I take this upon me my lord?

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.p: Hence with this trash, we have too long forborn to taste heavens blessings fully, which to our duty had more enabled us, rush thou'rt some angel.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Rather some devil sent to bewitch our souls.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Subprior no more.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: I must speak, hear me brothers,
Shall we (Bound by solemn oaths) t'abjure the world,
And all her sorceries ▪ to whom night and day
Are as one hour of prayer? whose temperance makes us
Endure what fulfilled belly gods admire;
Shall we (By zealous patrons) tied to observe
Dirges and requiems for their peaceful souls,
In gluttonous riot bury sacred alms!
Turn sanctimonious zeal and charity
To loathsome surfeit? and those well-got goods
Our benefactors saved, by their own fasts
And moderate living, shall we feed upon
Full-gorging us till we vomit? forefend it heaven!
By all the saints, by him first taught our order
What temperance was, here shall poor Clement feed,
Till his o'erwearied life, takes her last leave
Of this all tempting world where all sins breed.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: How's this? are you become our confessor?
Best thrust us out at gates, lock up the cloister,
And call in whom you like: be you the prior.
Speak are you agreed, rush be our master-cook?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: You have my voice.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Do you all consent?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Yes, all.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: First send this fiend to banishment.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: We have most voices on our side.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: You may;
'Las! most men covet still the broadest way.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Cive rush his charge then, Scumb: you must resign.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: With a good maw, I shall have a fatter office to be his scullion.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Worthy lord prior, hear me yet,
I must not my profession let,
to Scumbroath, what I know I'll teach,
To make candles, jellies, leech,
Syrup of violets, and of roses,
Cow slip salads, and kick-choses,
Preserve the apricock, and cherry,
Damsin-pear-plum, raspis berry;
Potates ike if you shall lack,
To corroborate the back:
A hundred more shall rush device,
And yet to early matin's rise,
Our lady's office, sing at prime,
At evensong, and at compline time.
Chant anthems, aniversaries, dirges,
And the doleful de profundis.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Thou shalt not change thy order: sirrah, cook,
From rush take lessons against night, for fare
Abundance and delicious.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: I shall be greedy to learn of him sir, since your lordship is turned, our very Jack and his spits shall turn too,

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: What men are these?

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Welcome good holy father.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Thanks reverend master.

sp.speaker: 1, Pil.
sp.l: Blessed sir, according to the churches rite
We (Pilgrims, to Jerusalem bound) this night
Desire repose, and pious charity
In your most holy convent.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: You are most welcome.
Alphege, go lead 'em in.

sp.speaker: Shas:
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: 'Tis mortal sin.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Oh black impiety!

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: How? sin to feed religious votaries!

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Rather to nourish idle vagabonds:
the clergy of other lands, have with much plenty
And thrift destroyed those drones, that lazily
Live eating up the labours of the bee.
A churchman there cares but to feed the soul,
He makes that charge his office. Als misdeeds! alas!
They through the lawyer's hands are fittest to pass.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Can you hear this devil?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Besides my reverend lord,
These maunders here are spies, and soon bear word to prince's ears of what they hear and see.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Ha rush! thou speak'st right.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Damned iniquity!

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Hence with those runagates.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Come, hence.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Spurn 'em away.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: O had mine eyes dropped out ere seen this day.
Stay comfortless poor souls, my pitying tears
Shall speak what my tongue dares not, here holy men,
You ne'er shall say when next we meet again,
Friar Clement to the hungry grudged his meat,
Or to the weary pilgrim lodging, this makes you eat,
And when you have relieved your fainting limbs,
Commend me in your prayers, and midst your hymns
Thus wish, that he who did your journey further,
May never live, to break his holy order.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Old superstitious dotard; beat hence these beggars.

sp.speaker: 1. Pil.
sp.l: Many old men's curses will on his soul be spent,
Who thus defaces, charity's monument:

sp.speaker: Sha●.
sp.p: I told you they were curs, that cease to bark, no longer than you feed them.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Friar thou speak'st right:
Make haste with fare delicious, we'll crown the night.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Ha ha, laugh Lucifer, dance grim fiends of hell,
Of souls thou judge must, but most terrible,
I must exact a double pay from thee,
Ne'er hadst thou journey man deserved such fee,
Let me cast up my reckonings, what I ha' won
In this first voyage: charity! she's undone:
Fat gluttony broke her back: next her stepped in
Contention (Who shakes churches) now the sweet sin
(Sallow lechery,) should march after: avarice,
Murder, and all sins else, hell can device,
I'll broach: the head's in, draw the body after,
Begin thy feast in full cups, end in slaughter
That damnedest fury: o, but friar Clement's free!
True: hast no snare to entrap him let me see.
He's old, choke him with gold; hold on thy revels,
Pluto makes Sackle-soul precedent of devils.

div.stage: Enter K. Octavio, Narcisso, Jovinelli, Spendola.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What picture's that (Uncle Octavio?)

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The picture of thy state, (Drawn by thyself,)
This is that book of statutes, were enacted
In the high parliament of thy royal thoughts
Where wisdom was the speaker. And because
Thy subjects shall not be abused by laws
Wrapped up in characters, crabbed and unknown,
These thine own language speak.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hang 'em up uncle.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What says the King?

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.l: You must hang up the laws.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Like cobweb in foul rooms, through which great flies
Break through, the less being caught byth' wing, there dies.
No no, thy laws I'll fix full in thy sight, hangs a table up.
(Like seamarks,) that if this great ship of sway
And kingly ventures, lose her constant way.
Ith' bottomless gulf of state, (Beaten by the storms
Of youthful folly, raging in monstrous forms)
She may be saved from sinking and from wrack,
(Steered by this compass, for the points of it
Shall guide her so, on rocks she cannot split.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You are our careful pilot in this voyage
Of government, be you our admiral.
Wisdom and age being props, realms seldom fall.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Oraculous is thy voice.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How now count Brisco?
Methinks I read a comedy in thy looks.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: Has met some merry painter, he's drawn so lively.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Come count your news.

sp.speaker: Bris:
sp.l: I shall bestow them freely:
The physic of your proclamation works:
Your guilded pills (Rolled up in promises
Of princely favours to his wit, who highest
Can raise your pleasures) slip so smoothly down
Your subjects' throats, that all (Upon a sudden)
Are loosely given.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How? loosely given? why count?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Name but what sport, your highness would have acted
I'm prologue too●: your court must have more gates
To let in ruffling Saturday: without (Now) waits
Music in some ten languages: each one swears
(By Orpheus' fiddle-case) they will tickle your ears
If they can do't with scraping.

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: There's seven score noise at least of English fiddlers.

sp.speaker: Io:
sp.l: 7. score! they are able to eat up a city in very scraps

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.p: Very bass-viol men most of 'em: besides whole swarms of Welsh harps, Irish bagpipes, Jews tromps,
sp.l: And French kits. All these made I together play:
But their damned caterwauling, frighted me away.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: These sports to please
A prince's eyes?

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: How like you then of these?
The cittie-waterbearers (Trimly dight)
With yellow oaker-tankerds (Pinned upright)
Like brooches in their hats; in their fresh loves
A may-game bring, all, wearing dogskin gloves.
Made not to shrink it'h wetting.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Bid these poor men drink well, and so be gone.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: What will you have then?
Will you see the turner's show, bravely prepared
With colours, drums, and guns (With rust half marred
Bearing that, of which they long have been deprived.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Their daring giant, (Newly revived)

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: For Jove's sake let's see that.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: O fie (Prince) fie!
In thy court painted monsters, they come not here,
Ride forth, thou shalt meet giants everywhere .
Methinks (Young lords) your souls being new refined
With beams of honour, should not be declined
To sports so low and vulgar: but since the King
Of birds (The eagle) lets you spread a wing
So near his own, you should put up such game
As fits an eagle, and pursue the same.
And not like ravens, kites, or painted jays
Soar high, yet light on dunghills, for stinking preys.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Old lord you rave.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: What sports wood you devise?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Most fit for Kings. Were I (Before his eyes)
To present objects, they should all be rare,
Of Roman triumphs, laden with the spoils of war:
Or lions, and wilde-beares killed by active force:
Or sea-fights: or land battles on foot, or horse:
Such sights as these, kindle in Kings brave fire,
And meeting spirits that dare mount, mount 'em higher,
Where apish pastimes lay our souls down flat,
Grovelling on earth, base and effeminate.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I have bowls of this bias too, for your lordship's alley.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Trundle 'em out before him.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: The wooden-leg soldier,
Waits to present you with his show of war.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I marry my liege.

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: The scholar has his device, the mariner his.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: These are Kings sports indeed.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Will you see these?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Faith be it so; because we'll now rather please
Our uncle than ourself, pray fetch in these.
The rest cashier.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Send the fiddlers merrily home.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: And yet pay 'em scurvily! 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: And bid the water-bearers cleanse the city
There's many a foul thing in it.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Marshal 'em in.

sp.speaker: Bri:
sp.l: I'll fetch these worthy spirits in myself.
No, no, we'll aid you sir.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: March: and give us room.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: 'Sdeath! if these doting graybeards might have their wills,
We never shall have ours: let us cross them
As they cross us.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: How, how!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Every device
Their ningles bring in, abuse with scurvy jest,
Beet ne'er so good.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: If ninies bring away the nest.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Teach Iovinelli and Brisco when to give fire.
Drums and trumpets sounding,

div.stage: Enter Octavio, Jovinelli, Brisco, Rufman, the soldier, scholar, ma●●●er.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: I am a soldier.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: We know that by your legs.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Does my stump grieve you?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Not if you bestir your slu●panimbly sir.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: What hot shot's this?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: A soldier sir: that's all:
That's more than sir I think you dare be zounds! baffled
For my limbs lost in service! your noble father
has clapped this buff-jerkin, when this stump of wood
Has up to th' 'Knee stuck three hours in French blood:
When such as you, with your spangled roses, that day
Bravely bestirred their 〈◊〉, and ran away:
I'll stand to't, I.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: With one leg.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Yes: with one.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Young lords, thus to scorn soldiers, 'tis ill done.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Uncle, here's no man scorns 'em; must we be braved
By a staring fellow, for a little fighting? go.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Fighting! I cannot halt I, but speak plain,
No King on earth baffalls me, I'd baffle again,
Th' whole race of great Turks, had gem ith' field: I ha' brought
With me a hundred soldiers, (Old servitors)
Poor as myself in clothes; pick out five hundred
Of such silk-stocking men, if they beat us, hang us,
'Sblood if we toss not them, hang's again: a fort
We ha' built without, and manned it, this was the sport
A soldier wood ha' given thee: my one hundred
Had taught thee all the rules i'th school of war.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: All this I'll read without may me, wound or scar.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: What say you to an engine, that at once
Shall spoil some thirty men?

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Thirty men! nothing.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: If nothing! hast thou been beaten for this? farewell.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: I can fetch twenty fortuners have done more
With a bare goose-quill.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Mayst thou but live, to need a soldier's arm,
That laughed to see him bleed.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: You have lost the day sir, for your soldiers fly.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Fly to the devil let 'em.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Your leaders before.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: You fight all under one colours? do you not?

sp.speaker: Scho.
sp.l: Sir: these pleasures to the King which I prefer,
Flow from Jove's brain.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: Heyda! here's one has beaten out Jove's brains.

sp.speaker: Seap.
sp.l: Would I had thee hung up at our main kit.

sp.speaker: Sch:
sp.l: No sir Jove's brain, (Minerva Queen of wit)
If all the muses and the arts can fit
With their high tunes, such choice and princely ears,
Apollo (Father to them all) — appears —

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.p: Apollo was an ass; he let a wench whom he loved to be turned into a bay-tree, and now she's glad for a penny to stick alehouse-widows, and wind dead corses.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Let Apollo go and lie with his own daughters.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Are you a scholar sir?

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.p: A schoolmaster as I take it; and comes to present a very pretty show of his scholars in broken Latin.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Can we be dumb and see this?

sp.speaker: Sch:
sp.l: O hapless learning!
Fly and complain, to heaven (Where thou wert born)
That thou (Whom Kings once nursed,) art now their scorn.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: How blows the wind sir?

sp.speaker: Seaf:
sp.l: Wind! is north-north-west.

sp.speaker: Nar:
sp.l: To hoist your sails up too, I think 'tis best.

sp.speaker: Sea:
sp.p: A black gust is coming: up a low-there heigh: a young man up tooth top-mast-head, and lookout: stand to your sails: stand to your topsails: let go your harriars, let go, amain lovere amain, quick, quick, good-fellows.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.p: He's mad.

sp.speaker: Sea:
sp.p: Who's at helm? bear up hard: and hard up: and thou beest a man bear up; starboard, port-again: off with your drablers, and your banners; our with your courses: ho, — I spy two ships yonder, that yaw too and again, they have both sprung a leak, I think the devil is sucking tobacco, here's such a mist: out with your boat, and you besmen, cut down mast-bith-board; bear up,
sp.l: I'm a blunt-fellow you see, all I say is this,
You that scorn 〈…〉, shall a seaman miss.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Now by my life I have patient stood too long.
To see rich merit and love, paid with base wrong:
Learning! and arms! and traffic! the triple wall
That fortifies a kingdom, raze 'em down all!
This seaman, (He that dearest earns his bread)
Had rigged and manned 4 galleys bravely furnished,
With soldiers, rowers, and fireworks for a sea-fight.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You are full of squibs too, pray go fire 'em all.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Must I be then cashiered too? marry and shall.
To save thy sinking honour, I'll send hence
These men with thanks, with praise, and recompense.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Pray do.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Brave Shalcan-bohor, all this while
Our eye has followed yours, and seen it smile,
(As 'twere in scorn) of what these men could do,
Which made us slight them off; to engross you
(Our best and richest prize:) ith' courts of Kings
Through which you ha' passed, you ha' seen wonders, show 'em.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: I shall at opportune hours. If your grace
Arride the toys, they bragged of (Fireworks,
And such light-stuffs) sit fearless without danger
Of murdering shot, which villains might discharge
In (Idle counterfeit sea-fights) you shall see
At opening of this hand, a thousand balls
Of wildfire, flying round about the air — there.
Fireworks on lines.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Rare, rare.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'Tis excellent s'death from whence flew they?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Hell, I think.

sp.speaker: Jon.
sp.p: Hell! Nay, if any that are in hell, skip up ever so nigh heaven, as these devils that spit fire did, I'll drink nothing but gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Ha, ha, a trifle this. Your scholar there,
Come with his arts and muses shallow, leaden brain,
Your swaggering soldier, lead a tottered train
Of ruffianly boot-halers: I noted all
These feasts for Kings: ith' garden of variety
The vast world! you are starved midst your satiety,
pluck no one apple from the golden tree,
But shake the fruit of every pleasure down.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thanks Bohor; why else wears a King his crown?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Shalcan, all Naples shall not buy thee from me.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Nor you and these from me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ask what thou wilt have
But to stay here.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Lo, this is all I crave.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thou hast our fast embraces.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Swift as man's thought,
Various delights shall be each minute born,
And die as fast that fresh may rise; we scorn
To serve up one dish twice; be't ne'er so rare,
Will you that 'gainst tomorrow I prepare
A feast of strange mirth for you?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Dear Bohor do.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: I shall; nor do I thus your love pursue,
With servile hopes of gold, I need it not:
If out the jaws of hell gold may be got
Black arts are mine to do't; and what delights
Those work be yours.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thou art gracious in our sight.
sp.stage: ¶ A table is set out by young fellows like merchant's men, books of accounts upon it, small desks to write upon, they sit down to write tickets, Lurchall with them.
sp.l: 1 come fellow Lurchall write.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Fuh, stay not for me,
I shall outgo you all.
2 I hold 5. Crowns,
We all leave you behind us.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Don; but I
sp.p: Must not leave you behind me; what pains a poor devil takes to get into a merchant? he's so civil,
sp.l: One of hell must not know him, with more ease
a devil may win ten gallants, than one of these,
Yet a merchant's wife, before these ten is won
To entertain her devil, if pride be one.
But Lurchall, now thou'rt in, and for years bound,
To play the merchant, play him right: thou'st found
A master, who more villainy has by heart,
Than thou by rote; see him but play his own part,
And thou dost hell good service; Bartervile,
There's in thy name a harvest makes me smile.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Lurchall: — within

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: My master calls.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I.
sp.stage: Men to and fro bring in bags, and have bills.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: O, art there?
This day twixt one and two a gallants bound
To pay 400. Crowns to free his lands
Fast mortgaged to me, Lurchall, got thee up high
Into my turret, where thou mayest espy
All comers every way; if by thy guess,
Thou seest the gull make hither.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: Barr.
sp.l: That, his hour
Lie gasping, at the last minutes; let him beat at door,
Within I'll beat his heart out.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: I'll let him stand.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: Do, take my watch, go faster. All his land
Is summed with these two figures, (2. and 1.)
At passed one, (His,) strike but two, 'tis mine own.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: I'll turn the wheels: and spin the hours up faster

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: The city-clocks then strike, and kill thy master.
Would all the citie-sextons, at my cost
Were drunk this day 4. hours.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: Troth so would I,
And we their jackesath clockhouse.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: We'd strike merrily.
Fly up to'th topath house,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: There sir, I'll sit,
And croak like a raven, to damn thee in hell's pit.

div.stage: Bartervile set amongst his men reading a long scroll.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How goes this month?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Much shorter than the last.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Weddings this month 12. thousand: not worth the scoring,
But think there's little marrying, we ha' so much whoring.
Grinding mills so much-used; about the city
Such grinding, yet no more money; suits in law,
Full brought to an end this month, no more but ten:
This law will beggar us: had I the bags again,
I bought this cumbrous office with, the King
Should make his best of't: he that did farm't before
Had it for less than I, yet received more.
How much remains of the salt tribute due?

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: 7000. Crowns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That's well: a savoury sum:
These our Italian tributes, were well devised,
Methinks 'tis fit a subject should not eat
But that his prince from every dish of meat
Should receive nourishment: for (Being the head)
Why should he pine, when all the body is fed?
Besides, it make us more to awe a King,
When at each bit we are forced to think on him.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: What payment's this?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: The pension of the stews, you need not untie it, I brought it but now from the sealers office: there's not a piece there, but has a hole in't, because men may know where 'twas had, and where it will be taken again: bless your worship? Stew-money sir, stew-prune cash sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They are sure, though not the soundest pay masters,
Read what's the sum.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: But bore 200. crowns.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: They are bare crowns indeed sir, and they came from animals and vermin that are more bare: we that are clerks of these flesh-markets have a great deal of rotten mutton lying upon our hands, and find this to be a sore payment.

sp.speaker: B●r.
sp.l: Well, well, the world will mend.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: So our surgeons tell 'em every day; but the pox of mendment I see.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do not your gallants come off roundly then?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Yes sir, their hair comes off fast enough, we turn away cracked French crowns every day. I have a suit to your worship in behalf of all our dealers in small wares, our freewhores sir, you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: If your whores are known, what's thy suit?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I should have brought a petition from 'em, but that 'tis put off sir, till cleansing-week, that they may all be able to set to their hands, or else a whore's mark.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Well, well, what's their request?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Marry sir, that all the shee-tobacco-shops, that creep up daily in every hole about the city, may be put to silence.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why pray thee honest fellow?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I thank your good worship, I had not such a sweet bit given me this 7 years, honest fellow: marry sir I'll open to you your suppliants cases: they that had wont to spend a crown about a smock, have now their delight dog-cheap, but for spending one quarter of that money in smoke: besides sir, they are not contented to rob us of our customs only, but when their pipes are foul with spitting and drivelling in those foresaid shops, they have no place to burn 'em in, but our houses.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Draw their petition, and we'll see all cured.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Let a frost come first sir: I thank your venerable worship; the pox gnaw out so many small guts as have paid thee crowns.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The tide's against you sir, the crowns are come.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How goes my watch?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: As most watches use to go sir, sleepily, heavily.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: Not reached to one yet; wert thou to be hanged,
The hour had galloped.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I spurred it all that I could.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Sdeath keek his hour, heaven help poor citizens,
If gentlemen grow thus wary: let him in.
Barren now, that hast in craft so fruitful been.
Your business sir to me.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Do you not know me sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No in good truth sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent:
sp.l: To know you I am bold sir,
You have lands of mine in mortgage, this is my day,
And here's your crowns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Signior Innocentio;
My memory had quite lost you, pray sit both,
A bowl of wine here.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Sir it shall not need:
Please you to fetch my evidence, whilst we tell.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What needs this forward spring? faith two months hence
Had been to me as welcome.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Sir I thank you.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Your hour draws on signior Innocentio,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Go beat a drum ith' garret, that no tongues
Of clocks be heard but mine.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Little past one.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Wind, wind.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thus windest thou to damnation.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: I'll part with none sir, pardon me, till I see
Your writings: will you fetch the evidence sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What evidence sir, have I of yours?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: My friend sir, whose money he lends me to redeem my mortgage.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Which you would have for your security.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: 'Tis so sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: No sir Innocentio, tomorrow on your bare word will I lend you 30. crowns more: I love you sir, and wish you beware whose hands you fall into: the worlds a serpent.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: This does but spend the hour sir, will you take your money?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Let him see my writings then.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Have you such covenant from me? I remember none.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Your conscience is sufficient covenant sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ha! what's that conscience? I know no law-termes I,
Talk to me as to citizen.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: We'll dally no longer;
We knew what snake would sting us, and therefore brought
Our medicine 'gainst his venom: you'll keep the writings,
And we'll ith' court of conscience tender your crowns,
Whither this writ does summon you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A fox, and o'ertaken?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Serve writs upon me, yet keep my money too?
Dull slave hast thou no brain?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Brain! try this.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: Will you as fits a christian give us in
What is our right, and take your crown's sir yet?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: 'Tis good to try men's patience, fetch me down
Those writing on my pillow, there they ha' slept
These two hours for you: must not friends jest? ha!

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Yes sir: let your men tell, just 400. crowns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Besides the use.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: The use is there too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Hold: I'll take it without telling, put it up.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Not till we see the writings.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Dare you touch it?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Dare! yea sir, and dare stab him to the heart,
Offers to take it from us:

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Who stabs first? Flings money amongst it.
Now touch it if you dare: there's gold of mine,
And if they lay one finger on't, cry thieves,
They come to rob me, touch it if you dare.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: Damned wretch, thou wilt go quick to hell I fear.

sp.speaker: A●r.
sp.l: No sir, the devil shall fetch me when I go.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That all my errand.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: We are cheated both.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Proceed, in your chancery suit, I have begun your bill.
Humbly complaining.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Of thee villain he complain
That sells thy soul for money, devils on earth dwell,
And men are nowhere , all this world is hell.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I kiss thy forehead, my witty Oedipus
That canst unfold such riddles: one rings.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Sir, I am bound
To do you all service, till I you all confound.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: Master Silverpen the proctor sir, sends word, if you come not in tomorrow and personally depose your payment of the 200. crowns, you'll be nonsuited.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That is a law-draught goes down coldly.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why sir? 'tis but your swearing the money is paid.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: If oaths had backdoors to come in at, without danger of damnation, to catch a man's soul byth' back, swearing were brave.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: What answer shall I give the proctor's man?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Tell him my master shall come in and swear.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do, tell him: on thee I'll build: now all my fear,
Is for appearance at the chancellor's court,
No trick to save that?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I have a brave one fort.
Bring in a pottle of wine: will Carlo here my fellow,
Depose a truth if he see it, to help his master?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What thou not honest Carlo?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.l: Here's the wine.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Set this to your head anon sir, when 'tis there
Away you, and tomorrow thou mayest swear
Before the chancellor, and swear true, if he
Were in that case thou leftest him, 'twere in vain
To hope he could live, till thou camest back again.
All knights a'th post learn this trick: the fits upon me now.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Take a good draught, 'twill help you sir: it gulps, he's almost breathless Carolo; away.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: He's gone, he's gone sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: One gulp more had choked me;
This wine had washed my fears off, thou'st given me power
To make me dote upon thee. Carolos gone.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yes and will swear his heart out, to your good.
Swear let him; be thyself and he damned too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So I may get by it. In my bosom sleep
(My dove, my love,) prosper but thou and I,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And let all else sink.

sp.speaker: B●r.
sp.l: Let 'em: so I kiss gold,
The youngman's whore, the saint of him that sold.

div.stage: Enter prior, Alphege Hillary, and friars with pruning knives, spades, etc. met by subprior, and Shacklesoul.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Whither (Madmen) run you?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: To our vines.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Your vines?
(The tree of sin and shame?) this serpent here,
Has with that liquorish poison, so set on fire
The brains of Nicodeme and Silvester,
That they in drunken rage have stabbed each other.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Stabbed!

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Yes, they bleed a little, but have no harm,
Their young blood with the grape's juice being made (Warm,
They brawled and struck, but I kept off the blows,
Yet the subprior says from me their quarrel rose.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: It did.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: In very deed (For I not swear)
It did not sir: to me you malice bear,
As if that all such mischief done, were mine,
But cause yourself shall see how I repine
To see vice prosper, pardon me good lord prior ▪
If I a tell-tale be of what mine eyes
Beheld with water in them: sin will rise
In holy circles I see sometimes.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: What sin?

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: What haste thou seen?

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Would present I had not been,
But till I utter it, my clogged conscience bears ▪
A man upon a woman.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Ha ▪

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: I speak't in tears:
Scumbroth our cook, and a female I beheld
Kissing in our orchard: on her lips he dwelled
I think some half hour.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Shame to our reverend order!
A woman in our convent! Sin black as murder.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Our cook shall be severely punished: a woman,
A tempter here.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Abominable!
Rush, thoul't rebuke sin.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Though my lord I'm bad, I'm not given that way.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Let us some plagues invent to lay on this lecherous knave ▪

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Some light punishment
(Good my lord prior) suppose 'twere your own fault,
Whip as you would be whipped, the best's naught.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: He shall be punished, and then lose his place.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: That sir shall be as we will: to our vines: away.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: For shame give o'er, dare you profane this day
That is to holy uses consecrate?

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Why? what day is this?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Lambert the martyr.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: No matter,
To vex thee deeper, this whole day we'll spend,
Only about our vines.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: You vex not me,
But heaven: what warrants you to this?

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Our will.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Thou hast thy will, thy wish thou never shalt have,
In sight of heaven who sees and punishes
Men's black impieties; and in sight of these
(Sharers in thy full sin:) and in his sight,
To express whose vileness, there's no epithet.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: No matter what he says rush.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I'm known what I am.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: To thee I prophecy, (Vicious old man to thee,
Who erst with lift-up-hands, and down-bowed knee,
Seemest to have had work in heaven: now (Full of spite,
Only to eat a liquorish appetite;
Digst our religious wales up, planting there
Luxurious fruits to pamper belly-cheer ▪
(For all thy pains to dress it,) of this vine
Thy lustful lips shall never taste the wine.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Distracted fool, in stead of my just anger,
Thou only hast my pity: thou prophecy?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Laugh on, but since nor prayers prevail not tears,
I'll pour my grief into my prince's cares.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: He'll go and complain to the King.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Let him complain,
Kings cannot subjects of their food restrain,
Away.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Engender sin with sin; that wines rich heat
May bring forth lust, lust murder may beget,
But here strike sail, this bark awhile hale in,
And launch into the deep, a brighter sin:
Ho, glitterback, ascend, to shackle-soul,
To shackle-soul ascend, ho glitterback;
Thou richest spirit, thrust up thy golden head
From hell thus high: when? art imprisoned
In miser's chests so fast thou canst not come?
Or fearest thou thieves, or cutpurses? here be some
Can save thee from their fingers: when? Arise;
And dazzle th' approaching night with thy glistering eyes.

sp.speaker: Glitt:
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: How thou sweat'st with coming? Save me those drops
(Golds pure elipar) stilling from thy locks:
Shake from thy brows and hair that golden shower,
So: get home: quick: (To hell) lest hell grow poor,
If rich-men's paws once fasten thee, and beware
It'n way thou meetest no lawyers: they'll pull thee bare,
Hence: down.

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.l: I me gone.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Cool night will call friar Clement forth anon:
Angels, be you his strong temptation:
Wines lustful fires him warm not: at this spring,
(Scorned by the rest for him,) spread thy gilt wing,
Full in his eye; as he drinks water down
In streams of avarice, let his weak soul drown.

div.stage: Enter the King, Narcisco, Brisco, Spendola, Iovinelli, Rufman, followed by Astolfo.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I do beseech your highness, yet turn back
And comfort the sad lady, whose fair eyes
Are worn away with weeping.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: If her eyes be worn away, what should a man do
With a blind wife? kill her with flies?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I cannot abide a woman that's fond of me.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: I would love a woman but as I love a walnut, to crack
It, and peel it, eat the meat, and then throw away the shell.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.p: Or as noblemen use their great horses, when they are passed service: sell 'em to brewers and make 'em dray-horses: so use a woman.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: So so.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: The Indians are warm without clothes, and a man is best at ease without a woman: or if your highness must 〈…〉 have one, have factors to buy the fairest, do ate not any, 〈…〉 the Turk, regard none, yet keep many. 〈…〉 you hear the jury's verdict. 〈…〉 whose foreman's the devil? 〈…〉 counsel thee to thy destruction.

sp.speaker: K●n.
sp.l: Destruction? why? the heaven can abide but one sun,
I hope we on earth may love many men's daughters▪
Tell Erminhilda so: send her home to the Duke her father:
And tell him too, because the disease of marriage
Brings the stone with it, I hate a woman; I love not
To be cut: enclosed grounds are too rank.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Best feeding on the commons then.
Will you not marry this chaste lady then?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: No sir, and will you now my reason have?
A woman's is an insatiate grave.
Wherein he's damned that lies buried.

sp.speaker: O●●.
sp.l: On, on, away.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Brave battles I fight you, but I'll win the day ▪

div.stage: Manet, Astolpho, enter Octavio and Ermynhilda.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: I heard the story, tell't not o'er again,
'Twere cruelty to wound men, being half slain.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: 'Tis cruelty too much, and too much shame
That one of your high birth, youth, beauty, name,
And virtues shining bright, should hence be sent
(Like some offender into banishment)
Abused by a King, and his luxurious train,
Of parasites, knaves, and fools, (A kingdom's bane,)
For them, by him not cared for; you came not so,
But as his bride, his Queen, and bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: And yet am neither, from my father's court
Came I (Being sued by princes too) for this?
To see him, his subjects scorn, and myself his?
Once thought I that his love had been (As fate)
Unmoveable; and is't now turned to hate?
Yes, yes, he's wavering as the running stream,
And far more idle than a madman's dream.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Send to the Duke your father, let him enforce
Your plighted marriage.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: Worse than a divorce
No: to his eyes since hateful I am grown,
I'll leave his court and him, and die unknown.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: All runs I see to ruin.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If he pursue,
These godless courses, best we leave him too,
That land to itself must a quick downfall bring,
Whose King has lost all, but the name of King.

div.stage: Enter subprior with an earthen pot, and a langhorne; Scumbroath with him with a piece.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Get thee to bed thou foolish man and sleep.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: How? Sleep? no sir no, I am turned a tyrant and cannot sleep:
sp.l: I stand centinel perdu, and somebody dies if I sleep,
I am possessed with the devil and cannot sleep.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: What devil possesses thee?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: The fencer's devil ▪ a fighting devil; rush has committed a murder upon my body, and his carcase shall answer it; the cock of my revenge is up.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Murder! what murder?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: He has taken away my good name, which is flat manslaughter, and half hanged me, which is as much as murder, he told the lord prior and you that I was kissing a wench: it's a lie, I give him the lie, and he shall fight with me at single pistol against my caliver, do I look like a whoremonger? when have you seen a wencher thus ●iary as I am: rush thou diest for this treason against my members concupiscentiality.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Thou wilt not kill him, wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: No, but I'll make him know what 'tis to boil a cook in's own grease.

I am scalding hot; I am charged with fury, I carry a heartburning within me. I kiss a whore? I shall have boys cry out to me, now who kissed Mary? No rush, scumbroth shall give thee sugar pellets to eat, I will not be danced upon.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Let me persuade thy peace of mind tonight ,
Get thee to rest, if rush have thee belied,
Rejoice, by wrongs to have thy patience tried.
He shall forgiveness ask thee.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Let me but have one blow at's head with my cleaver ith' kitchen, and I freely forgive him, or let me bounce at him.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: These bloody thoughts will dam thee into hell.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Do you think so? What becomes of our roaring boys then that stab healths one to another, do you think they will be damned up too?

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: I think so, for I know it, dear son to prayer,
two sins beset thee, murder, and despair,
I charge thee meet me at my cell anon,
To save thee will I spend my orison.
In name of heaven I charge thee to be gone.

sp.speaker: Suc.
sp.p: Well sir ▪ the cold water of your counsel has laid the neat of my fury: he had met with his match, but I will shoot off my anger, I will be gone, and why? Look you, because the moon is up and makes horns at one of us; as the nobleman's coach is drawn by four horses, the knights by two, and the cuckold by three, even so am I drawn away with none at all. Vale, bonos noches: I am possessed still: it buzzes, here. Vale.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Blessed star of light, stuck there to illuminate
This world darkened o'er with sin: thou watchest late,
To guide man's coming home, showing thereby
Heaven's care of us, seeing how we tread awry
We have two great lights for midnight and for noon,
Because black deeds at no time should be done.
All hail to thee (Now my best guide) be given,
What needs I earth's candle, having the lamp of heaven?
Now benedicite? where am I?

sp.speaker: Rush.
sp.l: O whether am I going? which way came I?
Ah welladay, I come to fill my pot,
With water not with thee; thou art misbegot .
Else wouldst thou not lie there; what orphan's blood
Hast thou sucked out, to make this golden flood?
None drink this well but I, how is it than
Thou thus way-layest me, (Thief to the soul of man?
Would some poor wretch (By loss of law undone)
Had thee: go do him good: me canst thou none.
My wholesome cup is poisoned, it flows o'er
With man's damnation (Gold,) drink there no more

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Not taste what all men thirst for? old and so brave,
When money assaults, one combat more I'll have.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: So, ho, ho, father, subprior.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Who's there? what art thou callst me?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: One that feeds the hungry, the cook sir, scumbroth.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Come hither, I have for thee a golden prize.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Ha ha: he'll take it.
Villains and fools will ha' gold, (Though got from hell,)
But they who do so, (As thou shalt) pay for't well.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: But stay, father subprior, before we go one step farther, what do you think I have done since I went from you?

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: No hurt I hope, say hast thou?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Hurt? If I did hurt in that, how much harm do almanac makers, who lie coldly quivering at it all the year long? I did do nothing but stand staring at the man in the moon.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: And what good thoughts bred that within thee?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: This: I thought to myself, what a happy fellow that man in the moon was, to see so many fools and knaves here below, and yet never to be troubled with 'em, nor meddle with 'em.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: He's happy that meddles not with this world indeed.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: If that man in the moon should write a prognostication, o he should not need to tell astronomical lies to fill his book, nor talk in gibberish no man understands, of quartiles, aspects, stations, retrogradations, peragrations; centrical, eccentrical, cosmical, acronical, and such palquaical, solar, lunar, lunatical vaulting over the rails of heaven, that no Christian dare look upon their tricks, for fear his wit break his neck.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Thou puttest into a sea, thou canst not sound,
Ignorance still is foe to arts profound.
Come hither man, come hither.
