sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Art's profound, arts make men as very asses as women do, I have no art, and yet I know this moon that shines tonight , sees more than you or I do, for all your spectacles.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: True, 'tis the eye of heaven.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Which of the eyes? 'tis but the left eye: and the sun is the right: and yet the left sometimes sees more than the right, and the right as much as the left, there's paxonism for you father globical paxonism.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: I understand thee not.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: No, why here's the oyster opened, I say the sun sees much knavery in a year, and the moon more in a quarter ▪ the moon sees men carried by a quarelling watch to prison, and the sun sees the constable and the bookkeeper share fees the next morning.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: That's not well.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Yes, but they swear 'tis well: the moon sees bastards come bawling into the world, and the sun sees 'em shifted and shuffled in dossers, away to nurse, and that's the cause we have so many dosser-heads: the moon sees old curmudgeons come reeling from taverns with sipping of half pints of sack, and the sun sees the same churls the next day, soberly cutting any man's throat for a penny.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Enough of this: come hither: look what here lies.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: What here lies: marry, father subprior, the devil and some usurer's money have been here at their lechery, and see what goodly children they have begotten: if you will I'll keep the bastards at nurse.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: I am content that half this gold he thine,
(If it be asked for never, for 'tis not mine,)
So thou wilt promise tother half to give
To such as I appoint.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: By this gold I will lay it out bravely, as you appoint me ▪

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Look not to prosper; if thou dealest amiss;
good works are keys opening the gates of bliss,
That golden key, thou in that heap mayst find;
If with it thou relieve the lame, sick, blind ▪ and hungry

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: I will do it I protest.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: One half bestowed so, take thyself the rest.
So fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Farewell good father, a fool: I'll give the blind a dog to lead 'em, the lame shall to the whipping-post, the sick shall die in a cage, and the hungry leap at a crust: I seed rogues, the pox shall: the world is changed: a beggar yesterday, and full of gold today: an ass today, and a prowed scab tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Glit:
sp.p: Stay: stand. — golden head ascends.

sp.speaker: Scu:
sp.p: Stand: cannot a gentleman grow rich, but he must keep knaves about him?

sp.speaker: Glit:
sp.p: That gold is none of thine.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: But all the craft in that great head of yours cannot get it out of my fingers. Zounds who the devil art thou?

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: A spirit sent up from hell to make thee rich.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Thank hell for it: hell makes worse fool rich in a year.

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: That gold I laid there for thee.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: When do you lay again, that I may have more of these eggs?

sp.speaker: Glit
sp.p: Spend those I charge thee first.

sp.speaker: S●u.
sp.p: Yes, head.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.p: And bravely I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: What need you be at such charges, I'll do't: but shall the poor be a penny the better for me, as the old fellow charge me, yea, or no?

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: No. ● within?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Gilt.
sp.p: 'Tis thine own genius cries unto thee no.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: My genius, I am a cook, my genius then belike is a scullion; but when this is spent, can my genius tell me whither I shall have more.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: More.

sp.speaker: Fl●t.
sp.p: More.
More.
More.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Because my genius keeps company with a great man, I'll take all their words; and his bond.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.l: When thou hast spent all that: I charge thee come
To the black tree, that stands in Naples grove,
Climb boldly to the top, and keep fast hold,
For there I'll rain on thee a shower of gold,
If what thou seest there, thou to any tell,
Devils shall tear thee.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: S●u.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.p: Ha, ha! down down bright spirit, thou wilt be missed anon, hell mint stands idle.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.l: Lose not that fool.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.l: Have care to meet at next infernal court:
The day draws nigh. — goes down.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I thank thee for this spirit.

div.stage: Enter K. Rufman, Narcisso, Spendola, Brisco, Iovinelli.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: You that complain 'gainst Bartervile, (Receiver of all our tribute-moneys) speak your wrongs; nay you have deafed our cares too much already, he does confess your crowns (Paid and received) but to give back your writings there's no clause, if them you'll win, fight it out by our laws.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I humbly thank your highness. A gracious doom.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: One day to try this plea, to hell thou'lt come. Ex. 2.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: To th' next, we ha' business of our own, toth' next:
Oh Bartervile! For these 200. crowns.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I paid 'em to that man.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Now afore the King
And his lords here, thou liest: thou'st paid me none.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Your choler's sirrah too high.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Though my collar stand
So high, it scarce bears up this falling band.
Thou say'st thou'lt swear thou'st paid it: uds nails swear so,
And the foul fiend go with't: 200. crowns?
I ha' lost as much at loggets: swear but to revel,
And spend't in hell, gallop thee and that toth' devil.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Man wherefore dost not swear?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Reach me a book.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let me before I swear, on my notes look,
I'll tell you the very day; pray hold my staff,
Till I draw out my false eyes.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Draw thy heart out an't wilt: thou mayst well say thy false eyes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The day: August, 14.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: That's now, be damn, and so away.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: On this day (August, 14.) I swear I paid
Into these hands, 200. crowns in gold.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Zounds not in silver: by this book I had none.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: One of you two is perjuriously forsworn.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: He, he, as I am true Curstian man.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: He swears,
To your own hands he paid them.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Else let that eye,
Which sees me play false, scourge my perjury
With fearful stripes.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: O justice I fallen down dead ▪
Would I had lost all ▪ though I had been cozened,
Rather than thou thy soul.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: He bleeds at mouth.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: See his staff (Beating the earth, for heaven loves truth
Is burst in shivers, and that gold he swore
Was paid to me, lies scattered on the floor.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: He comes again, the devil will not receive him.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Take him away, we'll punish him for this crime.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Beg his office: you a courtier?
I have a suit to your highness.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What is't count Spendola?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Master, look up man,
In this black trance had thy soul flyen away,
I had wrought hard and made a holiday.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Lose not a minute (Pew-fellow) leave him not yet,
I have whales here too, lie playing in the net.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I'll take this gold at venture, (Sweet young King,)
For all this hellhound owes me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Do, and be gone.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I am paid: the devils turned Puritan I fear,
He hates ( methinks ) to hear his own child swear.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The office of this perjured Bartervile,
I frankly give away, dividing it
To the count Spendola, and our worthy friend
Brave 〈◊〉 here; farm it to whom you please.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We thank your highness.

sp.speaker: Sp●●.
sp.l: Who bids most, he buys it.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If to his life ▪ the devil gives longer lease,
To build more work for hell; go see, and from him
〈…〉 of what he owes us.

sp.speaker: Ruff ▪
sp.l: That strict account I'll take.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Show him no favour.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If now thou art a just King, keep thy word,
With thy poor subjects.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How now uncle? why

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: This is thy day to hear the poor man's cry:
And yonder's crying enough, at thy court gates;
Five hundred 〈◊〉 heads, and scarce 10, good hats,
yet haberdashers too, of all trades some,
Crying out they are undone.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Undone, by whom?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Marry, look: by such as you are, who go gay,
Wear't out, book down more, set to their hands but never pay;
Never in dear years was there such complaining
Of poor starved servants, or (When plagues are reigning)
Mourn orphans so and widows, as those do
That owe these sorrowful papers.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Pray how can I
To their complainings add a remedy?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I'll tell thee how: are any here in debt
To merchants, mercers, tailors? let 'em jet
In their own satins, pay for what they ha' ta'en,
And these will go less brave, tother less complain.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha ha!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The mighty wrongs the weak, the rich the poor,
This man should have his own, could he grease more
His too-fat lawyer; that wretch for's coat does sue,
But his coat's gone, and his skin flayed off too,
Is't his purse be o'ermatched: these gross impure
And rank diseases, long unto thy cure,
Thy word's in pawn fort, these are the poors cries,
How wilt thou stop their throats?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: With halters.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Hang 'em! any halters here list so set down?
This lawbook speaks not so, yet 'tis thine own.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Still braving me with this? burn it.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Yes do.
If you burn all the week, burn Saturday too:
Do one good days-deed first, read poor men's plaints.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hell's plagues confound 'em: in their heads and thine
Vex me no more.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I warrant thee I'll save mine.
Holy saint pardon me, ('las good father, my brain
So wild is I forgotten thee, but I'll to him again,
sp.p: 'tis but an old man's head off. King take it, I'll speak whilst this stands on my shoulders.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But that you are. —

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: An honest man, thoud'st have this, o I beseek thy attention to this reverend sub●prior,
sp.l: Who plains against disorders of this house;
Where once devotion dwelled and charity,
There's drunkenness now, gluttony, and lechery,
Tell thou the tale.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Bad story soon is told;
Because 'tis foul, that leaf does all enfold,
Their sins grow high, and fearful, and strike at heaven,
Punish them thou, whose power from thence is given.

sp.speaker: K,
sp.l: Your friars so lusty!

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: All the barbers in Naples tell news of that priory.

sp.speaker: Bris:
sp.p: I would your grace would let me purge this house of her infection; bestow the livings of it on me, I'll sweeten it in one month.

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: He'll lay it in ▪ lavender.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: The convent, the demesnes, immunities, rends, customs, charters, what to this house of Baal soever is belonging — Brisco 'tis thine.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.p: Wilt rob the church too, (Now thou'st nothing left ▪ scarce for thyself?)

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: O heaven forfend such theft!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bestow it at thy pleasure.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Woe to those days,
When to raise upstarts, the poor church decays.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Call back thy gift (O King) and ere these eyes
Behold unhallowed hands to tyrannize
Where many a good man his his orisons said,
And many a requiem been sung out for the dead,
(Till I am thrust out by death) o let me have
My dwelling there, there let me dig my grave,
With mine own nails, (Shut up from worldly light,
Between two walls,) and die an anchorite.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: I refer you to your patron there.

sp.speaker: Rris:
sp.l: That's I:
Show me first where your abbey-gold sleeps, then go die.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: I fear religions fall: alack I see
This world's a city built by the most hie,
But kept by man, (God's) greatest enemy.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: Let ill-news fly together, thou art full of tears,
But I more full of woes, of cares, of fears.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'Sdeath shall we have yet fair weather?

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Here's one storm more.

sp.speaker: Ast:
sp.l: Calabria's Duke demands of you a daughter ▪

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Let me but lie with's wife, I'll give him a son.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: He sends for Erminghild.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Deliver her.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Shees not to be found.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You're an old fool,
To ask for that which is not.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Thus he says,
Deny her and look for wars.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: So go your ways.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: I'm quickly gone.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: With sack I'll swear you are,
This was short and sweet, — seems then we shall ha' wars,
Bohor, the drum must ▪ scold, the cannon thunder:
Fighting about a wench.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Tush, that's no wonder,

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Who bailed him out of 〈…〉
Out of mine eye.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: I never begged before,
Pardon his crime (I entreat) and back restore
Both your high favour to him, and his place.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let me want life, rather than want your grace.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Do you think I'll lose the King's gift?

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: I'll send you gold.

sp.speaker: Spen:
sp.l: That stops my mouth, pray let him still sir hold,
This office of receiver, I resign
That part which I have in it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: And I all mine.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Sirra, thank these lords.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I shall their loves deserve.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Bartervile, we have wars, I'll have thee lend me some ▪ 30000. Chicquines at least.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Take all my gold.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Well, get you home with your bags sir, we'll make bold.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: Your majesty shall have what bags you will,
Bags only, but I'll keep my money still.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Now Shalcan, some new spirit.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: A thousand wenches
Stark-naked, to play at leapfrog ▪

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: O rare sight!

sp.speaker: Iou:
sp.l: Your uncle.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, still haunted with this grey sprite.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: You need no tailors now, but armourers,
There's a dear reckoning for you all to pay,
About a lady; the Calabrian Duke
Is on a march: the lightning flashes now,
You'll hear the crack anon. Before the star
To call whom up, the wakeful cock doth sing
Be twice more seen abroad; at your city gates
The devil's pursuivant will beat (The cannon)
Will these brisk leaders (Stuck with estridge-feathers ▪)
Go brave your enemy now, and beat his back?
Save thee, thy kingdom, and themselves from wrack?

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Dotard, I scorn to take prescription
From any breath to which ours is supreme,
Stood devils with fireworks on your battlements,
A thousand armed Jove's at your proud walls
Hurling forked thunder, and the gates rammed up
With piles of citizens heads, our springtide pleasures
No adverse winds, no torrent shall resist ▪
Midst flames we'll dance, and die a nerenist.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Fight you, you're good for nothing else.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: They mock us.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: All stark mad: let us be wise,
And fly from buildings falling to'th surer side,
If we can his safety, if not, (Our own provide.)

div.stage: Enter Bartervile like a Turk; — Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou hadst like t'ha sent me swearing into hell,
I'll weave my nets myself, how dost thou like me?
Is not this habit turk-merchant-like?

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: A mere Turk sir, none can take you for less.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: King borrow 30000. Chequines of me! ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: But pray sir, what is't turns you into a Turk?

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: That, for which many their religion,
Most men their faith, all change their honesty,
Profit, (That guilded god) commodity.
He that would grow damned-rich, yet live secure,
Must keep a case of faces, sometimes demure.
Sometimes a grum-surly sir, now play the Jew,
Than the precisian; not a man we'll view.
But varies so. Myself, (Of bashful nature)
Am thus supplied by art.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mine own dear creature.
But sit, your aims, and ends in this.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Marry these —
A hundred thousand-florens fill my coffers,
Some of it is mine own, and some the Kings,
some taken up at use of sundry merchants,
To pay at six six months, on mine own band,)
Sue that, I'll keep the moneys in my hand.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You'll break sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Not mine own neck, but their backs;
To get their moneys, Bartaruile must die,
Make will, name an executer, which am I.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Rare!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Given out his kinsman, lately employed him in Turkey.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What will hence befall?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Like an executer will I cozen all.
Make creditors orphans, and widows spend those tears
They saved from their late husbands burials;
They get not ij. d. it'h pound.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: They'll tell the King.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The King? ha ha: the King is going this way;
He means to borrow,
(If the wars holds) my gold: yes: when tomorrow.
All debts of mine, on him shall be conferred,
I ha' briefs and tickets which from time to time
Show what large sums his minions ha' fetched from me,
His tribute money has paid it, that's no matter,
The world bites these dead, whom alive they flatter.
And so must I; then give it out I left
A complete state, but the King's death bereft
Me of those sums he owed.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Say the King prevails.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: With that wind must I likewise shift my sail:
And where the fox gets nothing, will turn ape,
Make legs, crouch, kiss my paw, present some stale
Device of virtue's triumph to express
How much I joy him safe, with nothing less.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: But how can you excuse your turning Turk?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Easiest of all: I'll swear, this saved my life,
Pursued by kennels of barking creditors:
for my much love to him, and thus being forced
To walk obscure, my credit fell to wrack,
Want of return made all my factors break,
In parts remote; to recompense which loss,
And that with safety I may give direction
To my disturbed state, crave I the King's protection.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Protection! what's that?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A merchant, and yet knowest not
What a protection is? I'll tell thee.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Pray sir, for I never broke with any man.

sp.speaker: B●r.
sp.l: It is a buckler of a large fair compass
Quilted within with fox-skinnes: in the midst
A pike sticks out, (Sometimes of two years long,
And sometimes longer.) And this pike keeps off
Sergeants and bailiffs, actions, and arrests:
'Tis a strong charm 'gainst all the noisome smells
Of counters, tailors, garnishes, and such hells;
By this, a debtor crazed, so lusty grows,
He may walk by, and play with his creditor's nose.
Under this buckler, here I'll lie and fence.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You have outreached me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll outreach the devil:
But I tempt danger: go thou and fetch some friar
As if (At point of death,) I did desire,
(No, Bartervile did desire (To make confession:
If any creditors beat, or rail at door,
Upstarts this Turk and answers them.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why fetch I a friar?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have a reaching plot in that (Boy) hasten,
That we may smile in our securer port:
Seeing others sea tossed: why 'tis but a sport
For him that's safe, to see the proud waves swallow
Whole fleets of wretched souls: it needs must follow,
Nature sent man into the world, (Alone,)
Without all company, but to care for one, and that I'll do.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: True city doctrine sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Away, thy haste, our richest love shall earn,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I came to teach, but now ( methinks ) must learn.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: What says the prodigal child in the painted cloth? when all his money was spent and gone, they turned him out unnecessary; then did he weep and wist not what to don, for he was in's hose and doublet verily, the best is, there are but two batches of people moulded in this world, that's to say gentlemen and beggars; or beggars and gentlemen, or gentlemanlike beggars, or beggarlike gentlemen; I rank with one of these I am sure, tag and rag one with another: am I one of those whom fortune favours? No no, if fortune favoured me, I should be full, but fortune favours nobody but garlic, nor garlic neither now, yet she has strong reason to love it; for though garlic made her smell abominably in the nostrils of the gallants, yet she had smelled and stunk worse but for garlic: one filthy sent takes away another. She once smiled upon me like a lamb, when she gave me gold, but now she roars upon me like a lion. Stay: what said head? Spend this bravely, and thou shalt have more: can any prodigal new-come upstart spend it more bravely? and now to get more, I must go into the grove of Naples that's here, and get into a black tree, hears a black tree too, but art thou he?

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.l: He. — within.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Ha ha, where art thou my sweet great head?

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.l: Head.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Or at the head, that's to say at the top: how shall I get up? for 'tis hard when a man is down in this world to get up, I shall never climb high.

sp.speaker: Glitt.
sp.l: Hie.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: I will hie me then, but I am as heavy as a sow of lead.

sp.speaker: Giltt.
sp.l: Lead.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Yes, I will lead (Big head) whatsoever follows, many a gallant for gold, has climbed higher on a gallows 'The storm even as head nodded) is coming: cook, lick thy fingers, now or never.

sp.speaker: Glit.
sp.l: Now or never.

div.stage: Rain, thunder and lightning: enter Lucifer and devils.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oooh.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.l: This is the tree.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: On which would you all were hanged, so I were off it, and safe at home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And this (I am sure 'tis this) the horrid grove
Where witches broods engender, (Our place of meeting.)

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Do witches engender here: zounds I shall be the devil's bawd whilst he goes to his lechery.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And this the hideous black infernal hour:
Ha●no appearance yet? if their least minute
Our vassals break, sink shall these trees to hell.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This grove I'll turn into a brimstone lake
Which shall be ever-burning.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: The best is, if I be a match in the devil's tinderbox, I can stink no worse than I do already.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not yet come ▪ oooh!

div.stage: Enter shacklesoul, rufman, embrace, and Lurchall, at several doors with other devils.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oooh, oooh.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Sure the fear no Christian
Devils, they so love one another.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Stand forth.

div.stage: Sits under the tree all about him.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Friar rush amongst 'em

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And here unlade you of that precious freight
For which you went, (Men's souls;) what voyage is made?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: No saving voyage, but a damning.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: I thought the devil was turned merchant, there's so many pirates at sea.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Ith' court of Naples have I prospered well,
And brave souls shall I shortly ship to hell ▪
In sensual streams, courtier and King I ha' crowned,
from whence war is flowing, whose tide shall all confound.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: Are there gentlemen devils too? this is one of those, who studies the black art, that's to say, drinks tobacco.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Are all then good ith' city?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No Lucifer.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: No nor scarce ith' suburbs.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Great prince of devils,
Thy hests I have obeyed,
I am bartering for one soul, able to lade
An argosy; if city, oaths, if perjuries,
Cheatings, or gnawing men's souls by usuries,
If all the villainies (That a city can,)
Are able to get thee a son, I ha' found that man.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Serve him up, — stands up.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Alas, now now.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Damnation gives his soul but one turn more,
'Cause he shall be enough.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p: It's no marvel if markets be dear, when the city is bound to find the devil roast-meat.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Has rush lyen idle?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Idle? no Lucifer.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: All the world is turned devil. Rush is one too,

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Idle? I have your nimblest devil been,
In twenty shapes begetting sin.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: One was to get me thrust out of the priory.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I am fishing for a whole shoal of friars.
All are gluttoning or muttoning, stabbing or swelling
There's only one lamb scapes my killing,
But I will have him: then there's a cook. —

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Whose arse makes buttons.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Of whom I some revenge have taken.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: The devil choke you fort.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: He mickle scathe has done me,
And the knave thinks to outrun me.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Not too fast.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Kick his guilty soul hither.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I'll drive him to despair,
And make him hang himself.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: For hanging I stand fair.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.l: Go, ply your works, our sessions are at hand.

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.l: We fly to execute thy dread command.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Would I could fly into a bench-hole!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But what have you done? nothing.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: We have all like bees
Wrought in that hive of soul (The busy world:)
Some ha' lyen in cheesemongers 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Would I were there but 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: For one half ounce, we had 〈…〉 soul

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: If he melted tallow, he smelled sweetly as I do.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: Walk round hell's shambles, thou shalt see there sticks
Some 4. butchers souls, puffed quaintly up with pricks.

sp.speaker: Scu. 4.
sp.l: Sweetbreads I hold my life, that devils an ass.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: Tailor's o'erreachers, for to this 'tis grown,
They scorn thy hell, having better of their own.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: They fear not satin nor all his works.

sp.speaker: 1. Diu.
sp.l: I have with this fist beat upon rich-men's hearts,
To make 'em harder: and these two thumbs thrust,
(In open churches) into brave dames ears.
Damning up attention; whilst the loose eye peers
For fashions of gown-wings, laces, purls, ruffs,
Falls, calls, tires, wires, caps, hats, and muffs, and puffs.
For so the face be smug, and carcase gay,
That's all their pride.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Twill be a festival day
When those sweet ducks comes to us: lose 'em not: go:
More souls you pay to hell, the less you owe.
This yew-tree blast with your hot-scorching breath,
A mark, (Toth' witch who next sits here) of death.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ooooh. — fireworks: Scumbroath falls.

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.p:
Call you this, raining down of gold? I am wet toth' skin in the shower, but 'tis with sweating for fear: had I ▪
now had the conscience that some vintners and inholders have? here might I have gotten the devil and all. But two sins have undone me, prodigality, and covetousness: and three pees have peppered me, the punk, the pot, and pipe of smoke, out of my pocket my gold did soak. I cannot swear now, zounds I am gallant: but I can swear as many of the ragged regiment do, zounds I have been a gallant. But I am now down, dejected, and debashed, and can better draw out a thirdendale gallant, that's to say, a gallant that wants of his true measure, than any tapster can draw him out of his scores: thus he sets up and thus he's pulls down; thus is he raised and thus declined:
sp.l: Nominativo, hic Gallantus, a gallant.
Genetivo, hugeous, brave.
Dativo huic, if he gets once a lick,
Accusativo hunc, of a taffeta punk.
Accusativo hunc, 〈…〉
Hunc, hunc, et hoc, with 〈◊〉 up her smock ▪
〈…〉 he's gone if he cries so.
〈…〉 away with him, he has the pock ▪
〈…〉 if the pox 〈…〉,
Genetivo, horum, yet he's a beggar in coram.
Dativo, his: his gilt rapier he does miss.
Accusatiuo hos, without his cloak he goes.
Accusatiuo has, to the counter he must pass.
Hos, has ▪ and Hae●, with two catchpols at his back.
〈…〉! A hole he desired, and to th' hole he must go.
Ablativo, ab his, thus many a gallant declined is.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Daughter to the Calabrian Duke.
The hapless troth-plight wife to your sad King.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Alack! what notes are these I hear you sing?
Pardon me madam:
Oh lady! want of you has bred much woe;
calamity does everywhere o'erflow,
All long of your strange absence.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I confess,
Loaden with your King's contempt ▪ and loath to bear
Shame to my country ▪ who from thence came freighted
With many glorious honours, I preferred
An obscure life before a public shame;
Oh then (Good father) be it not my blame
If my supposed death, on the King have thrown,
Dangers, which from himself are merely grown.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: What (Princely maiden) would you wish me do?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I do conjure you sir, by all the bonds
Tie you to pious acts, you would make way
To my incensed father; give him these lines,
This ring, pledge of that blessing he delivered me
At our last parting: add unto these, if ever
His daughter's memory to him were dear,
To wound the prince let his rash hand forbear:
Since through each wound he gives him, I am slain,
If the sad King you meet, venture to tell him
That more for him, than he for me, I bide,
And am his subject still, though not his bride.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: This shall I do, how shall we meet again?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Fears follow me so, I know not where nor when.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Hark how the sound of horror beats the air,
Your father's up in arms and does prepare
Sharp vengeance, for this city, woe is me: trust you
To me, who ne'er made much of woman yet,
Rest here sweet maid, till an old friar beget
What joys he can to comfort thee? Is Clement grown
A woman's man now? No, I am not mine own,
Where your command may sway me:
Much more in this,
Where heaven) through virtue's trial) makes you his.

div.stage: A table is set out with a candle burning, a death's head, a cloak and a cross; subprior sits reading: enter Shacklesoul, leading in an Italian zany, five or 6. Gurtizans, every one holding a jewel.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: That's he, and there's your golden hire to charm him;
Your fees I'll triple, let but lust's flame be felt;
The alpine-snow at the sun's beams does melt,
So let your beauties thaw his frozen age,
Music first t'act an old lecher, than a devil on hell's black stage:
Strike, strike your silver strings: brave set of whores?
At your striking up, devils dance, and all hell roars.

div.stage: Zany and courtesans fall into a short dance,

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: What sound offends mine ear? Soul of temptation?
Enchanters I defy ye, get you gone;
I'm blind to your enticements, from this I learn,
At how dear rate the careless world does earn.
That thing called pleasure: how many souls do fall?
(Sold for a little guilt top daub this wall?)
Hence with your witchcrafts, the sight of this drives hence,
All thoughts besieging our voluptuous sense.

sp.speaker: Shac:
sp.l: Another bait, at this he will not bite.

div.stage: The zany sings: subprior holds his head down as fast asleep .

sp.speaker: Zany.
sp.l: Will you have a dainty girl? here 'tis:
Coral lips, teeth of pearl: here 'tis:
Cherry cheeks, softest flesh; that's she,
Breath like may, sweet and fresh; she she.
Be she white, black, or brown,
Pleasure your bed shall crown,
Chose her then, use her then,
Women are made for men.
Pretty, pretty waist:
Sweet to be embraced:
Pretty leg, o pretty foot,
To beauty's tree the root ▪
This is she shall do't,
or she shall do't, or she shall do't, she shall do't, she shall do't
Kiss, kiss, play, play, come and dally,
Tumble, tumble, tumble, in beauty's valley.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: His soul is chained in pleasures, bind it fast,
If he break your charms ▪ the strongest spell comes last.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Hence devils incarnate, 'tis not the sorcery
Of your deceitful tunes, shuts up mine eye,
Mine ears are likewise stopped, hence, hence I say.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha ha, a man of ye, a clod of clay.

div.stage: Enter Shackle soul, or some spirit in a frightful shape.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Are all thy incantations spent now? art come again?
Base workmanship of heaven, what other train,
Were all hell's frightful horrors stuck in thy look,
Thou canst not shake me.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I can.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Thou liest, thou shalt not ▪

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I bring thee tidings of thy death this night ▪

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: How dost thou know that hour of my last fight?
False herald, minister of despair and lies.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I know to how many minutes thy days must rise.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Who gives thee the number.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: All things to us are known,
Whatever have been, are, or shall be done.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: I'll pose thee presently, what's this thou fiend ▪
Which now I have turned too, do but tell me that
And I'll believe thee ▪

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: I scorn to be thy slave ▪

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Down, down, and sink into thy damned cave:
Look here, dost fly thou hellhound? I dare thee stand,
O'er thee by these holy spells have I strong command,
Thy batteries are too weak: by goodmen's prayers,
The continence of saints, (By which as stairs,
They ascend to heaven) by virgin's chastity;
by martyrs crowned deaths, which recorded lie
In silver leaves, above: I charge thee down,
Howl where thou'rt bound in slavery, till the last dome,

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Storms, thunder, lightning, rip up the earth's womb.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Eternal power, thanks on my humbled knee,
Thou still to constant breasts givest victory.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: No way to conquer thee? I'll give thee o'er:
Never fished I so, (Yet lost a soul) before.

div.stage: Alarms ▪ enter King, Rufman, Spendola, Brisco, with drawn weapons. Jovinelli here.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Black horrors, mischief ruin and confusion affright us, follow us.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Dare them to the face,
And you fright them.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: No safety but to fly.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Whither Spendola, whither? better stay, and die.

div.stage: Enter Narcisco: King, alarms afar of.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: What hope? what news?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Is my uncle fled?

sp.speaker: Nar.
sp.l: He's is gone: — and fights against you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Follow him damnation,
That leaves his prince so in distress, in misery;
Oh bane of Kings! (Thou enchanting flattery,)
Thy venom now I feel, eating my heart,
More mortal than an Indian's poisoned dart.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: You're too dejected, gather head and fight it out.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The head's here, where are hands to lay about?

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Where is the King?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The man that title mocks
Is here, (Thou sad-visage man) are any hired to kill me,
Or betray me? let 'em come:
griefs growing extreme, death is a gentle doom.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Prepare then for the worst.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am armed fort: show it.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Thy kingdom is a weak ship, bruised, split, sinking,
Nor hast thou any pilot to waft us o'er
Out of this foul sea, to some calmer shore.
Thy people's hearts are turned to rocks of flint,
The scholar, soldier, and the mariner,
Whom (As themselves say) once thou trodst upon,
Now serve as wheels of thy destruction.

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: Flying swiftly backward, the kingly lions quailed,
What shall the weaker herds do, if he fall?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Let's fly.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Zounds whither?

sp.speaker: Bris.
sp.l: So we may be safe —

sp.speaker: Jou.
sp.l: But where?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: At Bartervile: the churl's to me beholden,
His house so stands, we may enter without fear.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Beet so, to Bartervile.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: What will your highness do?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Die Spendola, a miserable King,
None here can hinder us of that.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: How? die? — ha you any stomach to death sirs?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Not I.
Troth's, though you grow desperate, we'll grow wise.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Farewell sir, we'll save one. —

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O my cruelest enemies!
Stabs Brutus at me too?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Now mine own or never.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why art not thou gone?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Ay, I'll stick to you ever:
I am no courtier sir of fortunes making

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou art no wiseman to prefer thy love.
To me, before thy life, pray thee leave me.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I shall not hate the world so really
As else I would, oh had the ancient race
Of men (Who had long leases of their lives)
Been wretched as we are, no recompense
Could the gods have given them for their being here,
But now more pitiful wise nature grows,
Who cuts of man's years to cut off his woes.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: True sir, and teaches him a thousand ways
To lead him out this horrid giddy maze.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I apprehend thee, a small dagger's point,
Opens the veins to cure our pleurisy.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Than to be made your foes-slave, better die.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A hundred thousand deaths, than like a captive
Be chained to grace proud Caesar's chariot wheel.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Much less a petty Dukes.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Fetch me dear friend,
An armed pistol, and mouth it at my breast:
I'll make a way myself, and all my sorrows
Are made away.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: The best and nobler spirits
Have done the like.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Your bravest men at arms
Have done the like.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Philosopher's have done it.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Great peers have done it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: King's have done the like.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And I will do it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Nay it shall ne'er be said,
I lived a minute after you: here, here.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I embrace thee noblest friend.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Let's sail together.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Content brave Bohor: o! but whither? whither?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: From hell, (This world,) from, fiends, (In shapes of men.)

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: No: into hell, from men to be damned black with fiends.
methinks I see hell yawn to swallow us.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Fuh, this is but the swimming of your brain,
By looking downwards with a timorous eye.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: My soul was sunk too low, to look more high,
Forgiveness heaven. — alarms.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: The whips of furies lash me: the foe comes on.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And we will meet him, dare confusion,
And the worlds mixed poisons, there is a hand
That fights for Kings, and under that we'll stand.

div.stage: Alarum still afar off: enter a friar running.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Whither runs this friar?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: To save my wretched life,
From th'insolent soldier, threatening the city's spoil.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Of what house art thou?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Of father Clement's order, the Capachines subprior: a quick messenger fetched me to be rich Bartervile's confessor, who lies a dying.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A dying!

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: He does, but I
Have come thus far, with so much jeopardy.
That could I safely get the keys shore,
Nor the priory would I see more.
For charity's sake, direct me, and defend me.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: To help distressed men, religion binds me,
Shouldst thou in this hot broils, be met abroad,
It will be judged you leave your priory,
Carrying gold and silver with you.

sp.speaker: Eri.
sp.l: 'Las I have none.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But friar if you be thus taken, your life is gone,
Here, here, cast off thy habit, better that lie
Ith' streets than thou poor wretch; wear mine, and away
Strike down that lane.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Thanks master, for your lives I'll pray.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This Bohor shall disguise me, whither wilt thou fly ▪

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: I'll shift I warrant: hast thou toth' priory ▪

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If we ne'er meet again, (Best friend) farewell.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Not meet, yes, I hope, you must not thus cheat hell.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I will not trust this fellow: toth' priory, no:
Bartervile's confessor: if to betray
Thou findst the churl apt, leave him, if not, there stay,
The downfall of that prince, is quick and steep.
Who has no heart to leave, nor power to keep,

div.stage: Enter Bartervile and Lurchall, with the courtiers.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Make the door sure the house is round beset.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Beset!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Put up: fear nothing: armies should they enter, cannot here find you.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How shall we escape?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Send for your trunks and jewels, I'll ship you this night mean time, this unknown way, leads to a cellar, where a world cannot fetch you forth: in, in, if danger pursue you, in a dry-fat I'll pack you hence ▪

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Zounds into the dungeon?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So to Sardini:
Your cloaks and your gilt rapiers down, down, down.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How soon meets babels-pride, confusion?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What nest of birds are these new-killed with fear?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Fowle cannot last long sweet, therefore kept there sergeants.
In my cold cellar; stay, house beset? what sees?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Such as strike dead the heart, yet give no blows.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This — foot●a for 'em: proclamations Lurchall,
6000. Crowns are his, can these betray,
Soon earned, we'll share fetch, the calabrian hither,
They are here say: dam 'em.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: You shall be damned together.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Where's that devote sick man desires to take
Leave off this world? Deus hic to all now here.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Now dominae friar; what I to you confess
You are bound by oath to keep.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I aver no less.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Keep then this close, I am no Turk, not I,
But Bartervile disguised in policy.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Are you the sickman ▪

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Sick of a disease,
Bad as a plague to citizens, I must break,
Play a bankrupts part) I have money of the Kings,
Of merchants, I'll keep all, these are city-springs;
Here lies sergeant's leaguer: about my doors:
My house to me is an hospital, they the sores
Which run upon me vilely, (Peep I but out.)
To raze this dunkirk siege, thus cast I about.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Let's hear, pray how?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thus, thus sweet dominae friar,
I'll be like you, a Capuchine: so, by your prior,
Subprior, and convent, I may be fetched hence,
Spite of all showlder-clappers violence.
Though the King should lay hands on me, I would not tarry.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You need not.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You are my guard, my sanctuary.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But what your level in this, when this is done?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Alas ▪ what level but pure devotion?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The devil you have.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: When I die there, take all:
Will you go to your prior and tell this?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Yes I shall.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll send him an earnest penny (A 100. Crowns)
As the first stone my charity builds upon.
What drum's this? come, dispatch friar, and be gone.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Out of this hell thou meanest: yes I'll fly from thee
As from the devil's hangman: thou'lt else betray me.
World ▪ to what crest of villainy art thou grown?
When (Of good men) whole kingdoms scarce breed one.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Here's the Duke of Calabria sir if you have made me tell a lie, they'll send me of a voyage to the island of hogs and devils, (The Barmudas,) the Duke sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: His grace is welcome, 'las! I had more need
To have physicians and apothecaries,
Than fighters at my gates: Lurchall why come they?

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.l: Deliver up those monsters in thy house,
That have devoured a kingdom and the King.
'Tis death to thee, and him, if thou detain'st 'em.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I detain 'em, here, here, here.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Reward if thou deliver'st them.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I'm past rewarding in this world, I look only for good men's prayers, there's the key Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Unbind him: stay why did thy house receive them?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Full fore against my will: the bed I rise from
Count I my deathbed; for (Each minute) I look
When angels (Heavens good porters) will let me in,
Yet (Like my betters) I'm heavy laden with sin.
And being thus sick, and at last gasp, I sent for my near'st cozen, my executor,
Who seeing brave fellows beating at my gates,
Took 'em for honest men, let 'em in simply,
And undertook this night, to ha' shipped 'em hence;
My faithful servant telling me this, (In zeal,
To you and my country) I bid him, all reveal.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thou'st played a subject's part in't.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He'll lead you to them.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My lord, take force and seize 'em, ne'er stand upon
More trials; give 'em speedy execution ▪

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Come fellow. —

div.stage: Exeunt Ast: and Lurchall cum militibus.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Your grace has done with me?

sp.speaker: Cal●b.
sp.l: Go, look to thy health:
The crowns the proclamation promised,
Shall to thy man be paid.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thanks to your grace:
'Las what I did in this, was for no hire.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ha ha, the rent of a cellar never was so dear.
On beat the drum.

div.stage: As they go off; enter Octavio with Rufman and a guard.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Are the rest tanc?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The grand-pirate's here.
Here's the devil's bellows, kindled all those fires,
Which now are burning: this is the snake, whose sting
(Being kept warm in the bosom of a King)
Struck him to'th' heart: this he, who by the force
Of his damned arguments, was the first divorce,
Of the King's love, this is Bohor.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This that serpent,
You've all (Like traitors) wrought a prince's fall,
And all shall taste one death.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Sirrah, where's the King?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: Warrant me life, I'll bring you to the place where you shall take him.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Wilt thou betray him slave?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thou shalt have life.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: And you the King shall have.

sp.speaker: Oct:
sp.l: And the gallows shall have thee, else hang me. away

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.l: Alas, whereas the sub prior?

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Here, what ailest thou?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: Can you pick nothing out of my face?
Is there not a deaths-head standing on my shoulders?

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Scu:
sp.l: The lord Pryor is called away:

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Whither, by whom?

sp.speaker: Scu.
sp.l: By the great-head, I think he cozened me,
He is gone to the black-squib-tree, to
Judas oak! set by the devil, I told you then,
I saw friar rush spit fire amongst other hell-cats,
And ye would not believe me ▪ now I tell you,
That the prior is choked; will his choking
Go down your throat?

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: How choked?

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.p: Yes, choked: that of which men die o'ernight, and are well the next morning, wine has killed the lord Pryor: he ●●ud in a bravery taste the liquor of our vines, because you threatened he should never lick his lips after. And the kernel of a grape stopped his windpipe, for want of a scouring-stick.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Art thou sure he is dead?

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.l: How dead, because I would be sure,
I cut his throat of purpose, to take out the kernel.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Most fearful and prodigious, whither runnest thou?

sp.speaker: Scum:
sp.p: To see more throats cut, and execution of certain gallants is this morning. And I came running to see them, who like a whore spoils every good thing that comes into his hand. The hangman, I leave you to the gallows.

div.stage: Enter Bartervile like a friar, brought in by the subprior, the King, Shacklesoul, and Lurchall, with others.

sp.speaker: Rush:
sp.l: Welcome dear brother: now your heed must be
Not to look back at this world's vanity,
Riches and pleasures: you have laid aside
That garment, and must now be mortified.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: I am mortified, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: So is the devil.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Your gold and silver, you must see no more.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: O fie! give it every farthing to the poor,
When I have sent for't hither.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: That will be never.

sp.speaker: Rush:
sp.l: Your money shall be spent in pious sort.

sp.speaker: Bart:
sp.l: I know that: let my soul be the better for't,
That's all I crave for, after I am dead.

sp.speaker: Prior
sp.l: Many a requiem for it shall be said.

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: What drum is this?

sp.speaker: S●●ck.
sp.l: Friars stand upon your guard.
The priory is beset with armed-men,
Of which some troops are entered.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Lurchall I feel my weazand pipe cut.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I warrant you.

div.stage: Enter Calabria, Octavio, Astolfo, Rufman led by two holding pistalls, soldiers, drums, and cullors.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Guard the abbey gates, let not a friar go forth:
You have a King amongst you, which is he?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A King!

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: I know of none here ▪

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Villains you lie:

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: This caitiff does delude you, torture him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Hang him, and these up o'er the abbey walls,
Our wrath shall smite like thunder where it falls.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I shall like a dog, die without money, Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Tyrant, that royal heart thou huntest, is here,
Stand from me all, you have betrayed me all,
And I'll trust none of you, if the lion must fall,
Fall shall he like a lion; thinkst thou (Base lord)
Because the glorious sun behind black clouds
Has a while hid his beams, he's darkened for ever?
Eclipsed never more to shined, yes, and to throw
Fires from his sparklings eyes, thee to confound,
Touch not that noble friend of mine, (It seems,
For my sake marked for danger,) let your arrows
(Dipped in rank poison) be shot all at me,
Since all is lost, die nobly, and lose life too:
Oh uncle! must the first dart fly from you?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Into thy bosom fly I.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: To betray me?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: To fight for thee till I can fight no more:
Hadst thou possessed this kingly spirit before,
We never had left thee: what makes Judas here?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.l: Here's he that to the Duke thy life betrayed.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Bohor!

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Ay, Bohor.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: I told him where you were.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I tell thee thou'rt a traitor and I'll have
Thy head off, or thou mine.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Head?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Thou'rt a slave?
Thou seest Duke what to trust too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I have confessed, and shall be hanged, the King?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Our fair game come to this? our swords I see ▪
Must from your heartsblood let out all my wrongs?
A murdered daughter for just vengeance cries,
Whom to appease, your lives we'll sacrifice:
Beat the drum.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thunder mock thunder, beats ours.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: O let these fires be quenched out with my tears,
If waters cannot, (Duke) I bind thy rage
With this strong charm, and this read o'er that spell,
And let thy hard breast grow more flexible.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Where's Iovinelli; and that bastard crew
Of my false friends?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Beheaded.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: They have their due.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: The ring I gave her, and her hand: old man, —
Where's the old friar delivered these?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: He's gone.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Make after him, 'tis some delusion.

sp.speaker: Erm.
sp.l: 'Tis no delusion (Father) am I the ground
Of this your quarrel, which must both confound
If you go on: your battles thus I'll part,
The first blow given, shall run clean through my heart ▪
O noble constant maid, forgive my wrongs,
The warmth of heaven to a pining spring
Cannot such comfort give as thy glad presence
Does to my bosom.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Will you fight or no?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Twere madness to wish storms when fair winds blow:
Will you your faith yet keep?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Inviolate.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Then here end all my wars.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And all my hate.
Haste all these friars up to the abbey walls,
And with shrill voices, this our peace proclaim,
Stay holy father: Bohor, see you this done.

sp.speaker: Suf.
sp.l: Vengeance, I have now lost more than I have won.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I shall go scot free Lurchall.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Passing well?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They do not smell me, yet myself I smell.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Why sends your highness, thus these friars to play
Your herald's parts in publishing this peace?

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: There's in't a riddle (Uncle) which by none but by these friars only, can be done. — enter friars above. So: are you mounted? Sing now.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Sing.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Yes sing,
Like swans before your deaths: there you all shall die;
Cive fire to this most damned priory.

sp.speaker: Subprior
sp.l: Alack for pity!

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Father, but for thee,
Thunder from heaven had (Long ere this) to dust
Grinded these hellish buildings: that hand was just,
Which struck your vicious prior, so is our doom,
That synagogue of devils, let fire consume.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: But means the King that I shall burn here too?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou? the grand villain, give him a villain's due.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am no friar, see I'm poor Bartervile.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How? Bartervile?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: He lies the slave's a Turk.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A christian by this hand, your officer.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The city canker, the court's cozener,
A devil in shape of man.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Half that I have
I freely give, so you my life will save.
I'll lend your highness 30000. chequines.

sp.speaker: K:
sp.l: Ten kingdoms cannot buy thee; were there 10. hells
Thou'rt damned in all, 'sdeath! fie that house of devils.

sp.speaker: 3. Diu.
sp.l: Do: let's not want light to set forth our revels.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: King, little dost thou know, whom (All this while)
Thy court, this convent, and this Bartervile,
Have entertained: of hell, 3. Spirits we are.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Sent to catch souls for Pluto, our prince and master.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Defend us heavens.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Thyself hast burst those bands
In which I once held thee: these are in our hands.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: If you be right sergeants, for money you'll let me go. 5000 crowns I'll give but to go home.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: 3. no.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll put in 4. brokers to be my bail: I hope they'll be (Taken.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Yes as thou art, (To hell,) you dog leave howling.
This pile of green young devils, needs no fire
Of mortals kindling to consume, these frames,
You shall with us to hell ride, all in flames.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Catch.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: 3. Come.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Let every spirit his own prize bear

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: They are so heavy with sin, they'll soon be there.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Away then and be damned, would you all were here.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oooh — sink down, above flames.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Immortal thanks for our deliverance:
Race to the ground those walls: no stone shall stand,
To tell such place was ever in our land,
What wealth can there be found, give to the poor,
Another house we'll build and thee restore,
To former virginity: weep not for these ruins,
thou shalt from us have honours. Here we begin
Our reign anew, which golden threads shall spin,
Justice shall henceforth sit upon our throne,
And virtue be your King's companion.
War here resigns his black and horrid stage
To sportful Hymen, God of marriage.

div.stage: The play ending, as they go off, from under the ground in several places, rise up spirits, to them enter, leaping in great joy, Rufman, shackle soul, and Lurchall, discovering behind a curtain, Ravillac, Guy Faulx, Bartervile, a prodigal, standing in their torments.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Spir. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Dam. Torments inutterable! o! damned for nothing?

sp.speaker: Ravill.
sp.l: Terrors incomprehensible.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Back: you're blown up else.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Whooh: hot, hot, hot, - drink, - I am heart-burnt.

sp.speaker: Prodigal
sp.l: One drop, a bit.

sp.speaker: Faul.
sp.l: Now, now, now.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I am parboiled, I am stewed, I am sod in a kettle of brimstone, pottage. — it scalds, — it scalds, — it scalds, — it scalds — whoo●

sp.speaker: Diu.
sp.l: Ha ha ha:

sp.speaker: Prodigal
sp.l: But one half crumb, a little little drop, a bit.

sp.speaker: Faul.
sp.p: Towers, towers, towers, towers, pinnacles and towers, battlements and pinnacles, steeples, abbeys, churches and old chimneys.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Zounds drink, shall I choke in mine inn? drink.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Drink, drink, o! one drop, one drop, to cool us.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: So many tapsters in hell, and none fill drink here:

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ball no more, you shall be liquored.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Why art thou damned toth' horrors of one hell,
Yet feelst ten thousand.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Wherefore is thy soul
Made sensible of tortures which (Each minute)
Kill thee ten thousand times, yet canst not die?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Some sack.

sp.speaker: Prodigal
sp.l: Why for a few sins that are long hence past,
Must I feel torments that shall ever last? Ever ever.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Let the sack be mulled.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Why is the devil,
(If man be born good) suffered to make him evil?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Man is an ass, if he sit broiling thus ith' glass house
sp.p: Without drink: two links of my chain for a three half penny bottle of mother consciences ale: drink.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: One drop of puddle water to cool us.

div.stage: Enter Shackle soul with a burning torch, and a long knife, Lurchall with a handful of snakes, a third spirit with a ladle full of molten gold, all three make a stand, laughing.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Leave howling and be damned.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Here's drink for thee royal villain.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Shac
sp.l: Is't not good!
For blood thou'st thirsted, and thy drink is blood.
Strikes it so cold to thy heart? here's that shall warm thee (Again.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Damnation, furies, firebrands. —

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Prodigal
sp.l: One drop of moisture, but one crumb.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Art hungry, eat this adder: dry? Suck this snake.

sp.speaker: Prodigal
sp.l: Suck and be damned thyself: I'll starve first. away

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Is not this all waters? Ruby water, some ruby water,
Or else a bottle of postern water to save charges, or else a
Thimbleful of lemon water, to cool my stomach the ru●

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: By is swilled up all, here's lemon, down with't.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Foh, the great devil or else some aquavite woman has made water, it scalds me.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Oooh.

sp.speaker: Diu.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ▪ —

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hell grins to hear this roaring: where's this black child of fathomless perdition? rarest devil
sp.l: That ever hold in Barathrum? here, (Dear pupil)
Of a new damnation's stamp, saucer-eyed Lucifer,
Has drunk to thee this deep infernal bowl off,
Wilt pledge his ugliness?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Reach it me.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Choke with it.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Give fire, blow all the world up.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Bounce: 'tis done. Ha ha ha. —

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I shall be grinded into dust; it falls: I am mad.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: I am mad, I am mad. —

sp.speaker: A●●
sp.l: 4. Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Others.
sp.l: Ho ho ho. —

div.stage: Enter Pluto, attended by Minos, aeac us, and Rhadamanth, and 3. Faries.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Fetch whips of poisoned steel, strung with gloving wires.
And lash these saucy hellhounds: duck their souls,
Nine times toth' bottom of our brimstone lakes,
From whence up pull them by their sindged hair,
Then hang 'em in ropes of ice nine times frozen o'er:
Are they scarce hot in hell, and must they roar?
What holliday's this? that here's such grinning, ha!
Is hell a dancing school? you're in extremes,
Snoring, or else horn-mad? who are set on shore,
On this vast land of horror, that it resounds,
With laughter stead of shrieks, who are come to our bounds? ha!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Dread lord of this lower tortary, to thy jail
Have we thy busy catchpoles (Prisoners) brought
Souls, for whose coming all hell long hath sought.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Their names: is ward and Dantziker then come?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Yes: Dantziker is come.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Where's the Dutch schellum? where's hell's factor 〈◊〉?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Charon has bound him for a thousand years,
To tug at's oar: he scoured the seas so well,
Charon will make him ferryman of hell.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: Where's ward?

sp.speaker: Rush.
sp.l: The merchants are not piled nor pulled enough,
They are yet but shaven, when they are flayed, he'll come.
And bring to hell fat booties of rich thieves,
A crew of swearers and drinkers the best that lives.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ward is not ripe for damning yet.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Who is it then?
Cutlar the sergeant: ha! he come.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Yes Pluto:
Cutlar has been here long, sent in by a carman,
But his stern looks the fiends did so displease,
Bound hand and foot, he howls in little ease,
Having only mace to comfort him: he does yell,
And rave, because he cannot rest in hell.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: 'Tis not for him, that we this holiday hold.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: The bawd of Shoreditch, is that hellcat come?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: No: but sha's been a long time launching forth,
In a rosa-solis-bark.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Devils! who is it then?
Mall cutpurse is she come?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Our cousin come? no.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: 'Tis not yet fit mall cutpurse here should howl,
She has been too late a sore-tormented soul.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Where is our daughter? ha? Is she idle?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: No.
She was beating hemp in Bridewell to choke thieves,
Therefore to spare this she ramp she beseeches,
Till like herself all women wear the breeches.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mall cutpurse plies her task and cannot come.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: For whom then is this wild Shrove-tuesday kept?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: See King of gloomy shades what souls resort,
To this thy most just, and least-fying court.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Stay, since our jail is with brave-fellows stored,
Bid Charon that no more yet come aboard.
Seeing our judges of hell here likewise are
Sat: call a session's: set the souls to a bar.
Minos (The just:) Rhadamanth (The temperate.)
And Aeacus (The severe,) each take his state.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Not an officer here?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A fury.

sp.speaker: 3. Jud.
sp.l: Make an oyes?

sp.speaker: Fury.
sp.p: Oyes! All manner of souls, if they love their own quietness, keep out of hell, unless they have horrible business at this infernal sessions, upon pain of being damnably plagued for their lustiness. Back there, let those shackled rakehells show their faces.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Room here, we must come into the court within.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What damned fiends are those dare make this noise?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: A jury of brokers impaneled, and deeply sworn,
To pass on all the villains in hell.

sp.speaker: Rhad.
sp.l: Evil-conscience be their keeper.

sp.speaker: Fury.
sp.l: Look to the jury: evil-conscience look to the brokers.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Now proceed.

sp.speaker: Aeac.
sp.l: Stay, let the King of ghosts have first a view
Of those who are doomed to pains horrid, but new.
Then produce those who came to your prison untried.

sp.speaker: Fury
sp.l: Peace there.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Here's one, hell's tortures does deride. — Ravillac.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Arraign me, rend me piecemeal, I'll confess nothing.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Peace, thou shalt ball thy throat out.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Merciless hangmen! to tyrannize over so brave a Roman spirit.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Ho, ho, what country devil is this?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Thine own.

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: A French.
The eagerest blood hound that ere came from thence;
Is there a King to be murdered, whilst he does stand
Colossus-like, supporting a whole land,
and when by his fall that land most fears a wrack,
Send forth this devil; his name is Ravillac.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: Ravillac: I am Ravillac, that laughs at tortures, spurns at death, defies all mercy: gibbets, racks, fires, pincers, scalding oil, wild-horses, I spit in the face of all.

sp.speaker: Fur
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: No: were my tongue torn out with burning flesh-hooks, fame's 1●00. tongues shall thunder out Rauilla's name, extol it, eternise it, 〈◊〉 it! Canonize it: o!

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.p: Down with this devil to'th dung on, there let him howl.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: World's shall applaud my act, and crown my soul.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Another.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Come, you lean dog. —

sp.speaker: Prodigal
sp.l: One drop, a bit.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What's he? what starvelings this?

sp.speaker: Prodigal
sp.l: One that lacks a medicine for hunger: I am fallen away.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: From heaven.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: To'th common jail with him.

sp.speaker: Fury
sp.l: He must feed on beggary's basket: leave bawling sirrah.

sp.speaker: Prodigal
sp.l: Shall I be undone for a little drink.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No, thou'rt undone for drinking.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Starve him away —
What was he when he lived.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A prodigal:
Who (In one year,) spent on whores, fools and slaves,
An army's maintenance, now begs for crumbs, and raves
To see his sumptuous buildings, pastures, woods,
That stood in uplands, drowned in Rhenish floods.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Is here all?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: All! no, the arch-hellhound's here.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What Peter goner's this?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Speak softly, within an inch of giving fire, within an inch.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Had all thy grey devils in their highest lust sat,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: To have littered furies, they could not have begotten.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: One to match this: ith' dark he groped damnation,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Now, now.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Digged cellars to find where hell stood and has found it
There was but one villainy unborn, and he crowned it.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.p: So: all the billets lie close; glorious bonfire? pontifical bonfire; brave heads to contrive this, gallant souls to conspire in't, resolute hand to seal this with my blood, through fire, through flint; ha, ha, ha, whither fly myself to heaven, friends to honour, none to the halter, enemies to massacre, ha ha, dismal tragical comedy now?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: What does he?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: As he thinks, giving fire to powder;
Ne'er in any land could devils have found, such walks,
As he was beating out.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: His name.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Guy Eaulx.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Who calls? damnation stops throat.

sp.speaker: 3. Jud.
sp.l: Let it stop thine.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Am I betrayed? give fire, now, now, give fire.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: To burn thine own soul villain.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Pay him his hire:
He has a desperate rakehels face.

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: Had his plot ta'en fire,
One real me before any other had doomsday seen,
Kings who in tombs lay at rest had wakened been,
He was within 12. hours of he wing down
A whole land at one blow, and at once drown
In a flood of flames, an arch-royal with his whole fleet,
Of nobility and clergy: in a leaden sheet
Law and her children had been hotly wrapped;
Millons ere this had in our jail been clapped,
For damned arts not known now, which had then
Been rise, but now lie dead (Th' acts with the men.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Make much of this our ningle: for the rest
Deliver 'em to our head-hangman.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: When?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: In a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Min:
sp.l: How applauds Pluto
Our enginous tortures, and most rigorous doom?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Minos, thy doom is just; — but your all-faced caitiffs.)
sp.l: What fish in your infernal nets, drew you up
Ith' Naples' court, city and friary?
We charded you sail thither: is mischief's river there dry?

sp.speaker: Ruff:
sp.l: Dry, no: fat preys for hell we all did meet,
In court, city, country, nay, in every street,
In every house, within him, and without him.
He that wore best clothes, had some devil about him:
Courtiers from Naples hither in shoals are come,
Some for ambition, for flattery, and envy some:
Some, who (Each meal) eat subjects up, and wore,
Whole families in their shoestrings, such, and others more,
Being here, have been examining (Ever since
They came) by hells-clerk, (Spotted-conscience.)

sp.speaker: Min:
sp.l: Till the next sessions, these we must defer.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: None come froth' city, so many bad being there!

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: Yes, (King of endless horror) see who's here: Bartervile

sp.speaker: Plu:
sp.l: Richmen in hell! they are welcome, what's the grey beard

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.p: One that can buy thee and ten such as thou art out of thy sea-coale-pits here. Is not this Newcastle?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No covetous wretch: 'tis hell, thy black-souls prison.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: Soul in prison! I never had any soul to speak on.

sp.speaker: Lur:
sp.l: Now thou shalt find thou'st one.

sp.speaker: Rar:
sp.l: Can angels bail me?

sp.speaker: Min:
sp.l: Not all the wealth which the world's back does bear
Can bail thy wretched soul hence, now 'tis here.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: A thousand pounds. —

sp.speaker: Fury
sp.l: Where is't fool?

sp.speaker: Rhad:
sp.l: Thy wealths now gone,
Thy hands still catch at bags,, but they gripe none.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: What's this? —

sp.speaker: Omn:
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Aeac.
sp.l: Air, shadows, things imaginary:
That is thy torment now, which was thy glory.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.p: If you give me bags full of sawdust, in stead of money, my ghost shall walk.

sp.speaker: 3. Jud:
sp.l: To thy grim father of hell.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No, to my old brother, sir Achitophel pinch gut shall I: shall I?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Hence with him the, churl's mad:
In lethes-flood drowned all the wealth he had.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My chain, let me hang in chains, so it be my
Gold chain; thieves, thieves, thieves.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Throw him headlong into our boiling-lake,
Where molten gold runs.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: His thirst it cannot slake,
Seas could not quench his dropsy: gold to get
He would hang a city, statue a country. Even yet
Raves he for bonds and encumbers: to save whose soul,
(Though he fed none living) sausages were his dole.

div.stage: A confused noise to come pressing in.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: What coil is that?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: 'Tis a burning zeal must consume the wicked, and therefore I will not be kept out, but will chastise and correct the foul fiend.

sp.speaker: 3. Jud.
sp.l: What's this black incubus?

sp.speaker: Shac.
sp.l: An arch great Puritan once.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha! how! A Puritan?

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: An arch-great Puritan! How comes thy soul so little ▪

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: I did exercise too much with a lively spirit.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Are there any more of his synagogue?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.l: Yes, a whole hoy-full are landed.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Pl●.
sp.l: Are they all so black as he is?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Worse.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Sirrah, why being a Puritan is your soul so black?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: We were all smoked out of our own country, and sent to Rotterdam.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: How camest thou lame and crooked, why dost halt?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: All the brothers and sisters for the better part are crooked, and halt: for my own part, I never went upright.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: And yet a Puritan? hence with him.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Alack!
How can I choose but halt, go lame, and crooked?
When I pulled a whole church down upon my back.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Hence with him, he will pull all hell down too.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Let in the brothers, to confound this wicked assembly,

sp.speaker: 3. Jud.
sp.l: Thrust him out at hell gates.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: They'll confound our kingdom,
If here they get but footing: rise therefore, away;
Keep the jury of brokers till our next court day.

sp.speaker: Min.
sp.l: Adjourn this.

sp.speaker: Fury
sp.l: O yes! Sessions is deferred
Because of Puritans, hell cannot be cleared.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Set forward to our hall paved all with brass,
Judges we thank you: let our officers drink,
I'th bottom of hell's cellar, for their good service.
Since to this height our empire up you rear,
Hell shall hold triumphs, and (That's done,) prepare,
Again to walk your circuits o'er the earth,
Souls are hell's subjects, and then groans our mirth.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: If't be not good, the devil is in't, (They say,)
The devil was in't, this then is no good play
By that conclusion, but hereby is meant,
If for so many noons, and midnights spent
To reap three hours of mirth, our harvest-seed
Lies still and rot. The Devil in't then indeed ▪
Much labour, art, and wit, make up a play
As it does a ship, yet both are cast away,
(When bravely they have passed the humorous seas)
At landing, what black fates curseth both these?
Sail it, or sink it, now 'tis forth, and near
The haven at which it longs t'arrive: if there
It suffers wrack, the spitefuller rocks shoot forth,
Yet none may bring it home laden with much worth.
By your wonted gentle gale, (Sweet as the balm,)
Or by extending fair liberal palm.
To fan away all storms, if you see it lours,
The air shall ring thanks, but the glory's yours.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
